DERBY MUNICIPAL CODE 1996 
____________ 
A Codification of the General Ordinances of 
the City of Derby, Kansas 
____________ 
Beginning with Supp. No. 8, 
Supplemented by Municipal Code Corporation

PREFACE 
    The Derby, Kansas Municipal Code, originally published by Book Publishing Company in 1975, has been kept current by regular supplementation by Matthew Bender & Company, Inc., its successor in interest. 
    Beginning with Supplement 8, Municipal Code Corporation will be keeping this code current by regular supplementation. 
    During original codification, the ordinances were compiled, edited and indexed by the editorial staff of Book Publishing Company. 
    The code is organized by subject matter under an expandable three-factor decimal numbering system which is designed to facilitate supplementation without disturbing the numbering of existing provisions. Each section number designates, in sequence, the numbers of the Title, chapter, and section. Thus, Section 2.12.040 is Section .040, located in Chapter 2.12 of Title 2. In most instances, sections are numbered by tens (.010, .020, .030, etc.), leaving nine vacant positions between original sections to accommodate future provisions. Similarly, chapters and titles are numbered to provide for internal expansion. 
    In parentheses following each section is a legislative history identifying the specific sources for the provisions of that section. This legislative history is complemented by an ordinance disposition table, following the text of the code, listing by number all ordinances, their subjects, and where they appear in the codification; and beginning with Supplement No. 8, legislation can be tracked using the "Code Comparative Table and Disposition List." 
    A subject-matter index, with complete cross-referencing, locates specific code provisions by individual section numbers. 
    This supplement brings the Code up to date through Ordinance No. 2370, passed November 13, 2018. 
Municipal Code Corporation 
1700 Capital Circle SW 
Tallahassee, FL 32310 
800-262-2633 
HOW TO USE YOUR CODE 
    This code is organized to make the laws of the city as accessible as possible to city officials, city employees and private citizens. Please take a moment to familiarize yourself with some of the important elements of this code. 
Numbering System. 
    The numbering system is the backbone of a Code of Ordinances; Municipal Code Corporation uses a unique and versatile numbering structure that allows for easy expansion and amendment of this Code. It is based on three tiers, beginning with title, then chapter, and ending with section. Each part is represented in the code section number. For example, Section 2.04.010 is Section .010, in Chapter 2.04 of Title 2. 
Title. 
    A title is a broad category under which ordinances on a related subject are compiled. This code contains about 15 to 20 titles. For example, the first title is Title 1, General Provisions, which may contain ordinances about the general penalty, code adoption and definitions. The titles in this code are separated by tabbed divider pages for quick reference. Some titles are Reserved for later use. 
Chapter. 
    Chapters deal with more specific subjects, and are often derived from one ordinance. All of the chapters on a related subject are grouped in one title. The chapters are numbered so that new chapters which should logically be placed near certain existing chapters can be added at a later time without renumbering existing material. For example, Chapter 2.06 can be added between Chapter 2.04 and Chapter 2.08. 
Section. 
    Each section of the code contains substantive ordinance material. The sections are numbered by "tens" to allow for expansion of the code without renumbering. 
Tables of Contents. 
    There are many tables of contents in this code to assist in locating specific information. At the beginning of the code is the main table of contents listing each title. In addition, each title and chapter has its own table of contents listing the chapters and sections, respectively. 
Ordinance History Note. 
    At the end of each code section, you will find an "ordinance history note," which lists the underlying ordinances for that section. The ordinances are listed by number, section (if applicable) and year. (Example: (Ord. 272 § 1, 1992).) 
    Beginning with Supplement No. 8, a secondary ordinance history note will be appended to affected sections. Ordinance history notes will be amended with the most recent ordinance added to the end. These history notes can be cross referenced to the code comparative table and disposition list appearing at the back of the volume preceding the index. 
Statutory References. 
    The statutory references direct the code user to those portions of the state statutes that are applicable to the laws of the municipality. As the statutes are revised, these references will be updated. 
Cross-Reference Table. 
    When a code is based on an earlier codification, the cross-reference table will help users find older or "prior" code references in the new code. The cross-reference table is located near the end of the code, under the tabbed divider "Tables." This table lists the prior code section in the column labeled "Prior Code Section" and the new code section in the column labeled "Herein." 
    As of Supplement No. 8, this table will no longer be updated. 
Ordinance List and Disposition Table. 
    To find a specific ordinance in the code, turn to the section called "Tables" for the Ordinance List and Disposition Table. This very useful table tells you the status of every ordinance reviewed for inclusion in the code. The table is organized by ordinance number and provides a brief description and the disposition of the ordinance. If the ordinance is codified, the chapter (or chapters) will be indicated. (Example: (2.04, 6.12, 9.04).) If the ordinance is of a temporary nature or deals with subjects not normally codified, such as budgets, taxes, annexations or rezones, the disposition will be "(Special)." If the ordinance is for some reason omitted from the code, usually at the direction of the municipality, the disposition will be "(Not codified)." Other dispositions sometimes used are "(Tabled)," "(Pending)," "(Number Not Used)" or "(Missing)." 
    Beginning with Supplement No. 8, this table will be replaced with the "Code Comparative Table and Disposition List." 
Code Comparative Table and Disposition List. 
    Beginning with Supplement No. 8, a Code Comparative Table and Disposition List has been added for use in tracking legislative history. Located in the back of this volume, this table is a chronological listing of each ordinance considered for codification. The Code Comparative Table and Disposition List specifies the ordinance number, adoption date, description of the ordinance and the disposition within the code of each ordinance. By use of the Code Comparative Table and Disposition List, the reader can locate any section of the code as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
Index. 
    If you are not certain where to look for a particular subject in this code, start with the index. This is an alphabetical multi-tier subject index which uses section numbers as the reference, and cross-references where necessary. Look for the main heading of the subject you need, then the appropriate subheadings: 
BUSINESS LICENSE 
See also BUSINESS TAX 
Fee 5.04.030 
Required when 5.04.010 
    The index will be updated as necessary when the code text is amended. 
Instruction Sheet. 
    Each supplement to the new code will be accompanied by an Instruction Sheet. The Instruction Sheet will tell the code user the date of the most recent supplement and the last ordinance contained in that supplement. It will then list the pages that must be pulled from the code and the new pages that must be inserted. Following these instructions carefully will assure that the code is kept accurate and current. Removed pages should be kept for future reference. 
Page Numbers. 
    When originally published, the pages of this code were consecutively numbered. As of Supplement No. 8, when new pages are inserted with amendments, the pages will follow a "Point Numbering System". (Example: 32, 32.1, 32.2, 32.2.1, 32.2.2., 33). Backs of pages that are blank (in codes that are printed double-sided) will be left unnumbered but the number will be "reserved" for later use. 
Electronic Submission. 
    In the interests of accuracy and speed, we encourage you to submit your ordinances electronically if at all possible. We can accept most any file format, including Word, WordPerfect or text files. If you have a choice, we prefer Word, any version. You can send files to us as an e-mail attachment, by FTP, on a diskette or CD-ROM. Our e-mail address is: ords@municode.com . 
For hard copy, send two copies of all ordinances passed to: 
Municipal Code Corporation 
P.O. Box 2235 
Tallahassee, FL 32316 
Customer Service. 
    If you have any questions about this code or our services, please contact Municipal Code Corporation at 1-800-262-2633 or:

SUPPLEMENT HISTORY TABLE 
    The table below allows users of this Code to quickly and accurately determine what ordinances have been considered for codification in each supplement. Ordinances that are of a general and permanent nature are codified in the Code Book and are considered "Includes." Ordinances that are not of a general and permanent nature are not codified in the Code Book and are considered "Omits." 
    In addition, by adding to this table with each supplement, users of this Code of Ordinances will be able to gain a more complete picture of the Code's historical evolution.

Title 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 1.01 - CODE ADOPTION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2237, § 7, adopted July 14, 2015, repealed former Ch. 1.01, §§ 1.01.010-1.01.040, and §§ 1, 3-6 of said ordinance enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 1.01 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 2226, §§ 1, 3-6, adopted April 28, 2015. See the Code Comparative Table for a complete derivation. 

1.01.010 - Adoption. 
    There is hereby adopted, pursuant to K.S.A. 12-3014 and 12-3015 and amendments thereto and as heretofore authorized by ordinance, a certain code entitled "Derby Municipal Code," containing certain ordinances of a general and permanent nature, compiled, consolidated, revised, and catalogued as Titles 1 through 17, including certain titles reserved for future use, of which code not less than three copies shall be kept on file by the city clerk with the ordinance books of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2237, § 1, 7-14-15) 
1.01.020 - General ordinances-Exceptions. 
    In construing this chapter, the following classes of ordinances shall not be considered or held to have been repealed hereby: 
A.  Ordinances pertaining to the acquisition of property or interests in property by gift, purchase, devise, bequest, appropriation or condemnation; 
B.  Ordinances specifying the corporate boundaries of the city; 
C.  Ordinances opening, dedicating, widening, vacating or narrowing streets, avenues, alleys or boulevards; 
D.  Ordinances establishing or changing grades of streets, avenues, alleys or boulevards; 
E.  Ordinances naming or changing the names of streets, avenues or boulevards; and ordinances designating main trafficways or major trafficways; 
F.  Ordinances authorizing or directing public improvements to be made; 
G.  Ordinances creating districts for public improvements of whatever kind or nature; 
H.  Ordinances levying general taxes; 
I.  Ordinances levying special assessments or taxes; 
J.  Ordinances granting any rights, privileges, easements or franchises to any person, firm or corporation; 
K.  Ordinances authorizing the issuance of bonds or other instruments of indebtedness by the city; 
L.  Ordinances relating to zoning; 
M.  Ordinances authorizing contracts; 
N.  Ordinances pertaining to annexation, vacation, or exclusion of territory; and 
O.  Ordinances relating to compensation of officials, officers and employees of the city; 
P.  Ordinances creating or authorizing creation of a lien upon insurance proceeds; and 
Q.  Charter ordinances; 
provided; that the enumeration of exceptions shall not be held or deemed to be exclusive, it being the purpose and intention to exempt from repeal any and all ordinances not of a general nature, and general ordinances specifically excepted by this action. 
(Ord. No. 2237, § 3, 7-14-15) 
1.01.030 - Titles, chapters, articles and sections of the code adopted. 
    The arrangement and classification of the several titles, chapters, articles and sections of the code adopted by Section 1.01.010 of this chapter, and any headnotes and footnotes at the end of sections, are made for the purpose of convenience and orderly arrangement, and do not constitute a part of the ordinances, and no implication or presumption of legislative intent or construction is to be drawn therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 2237, § 4, 7-14-15) 
1.01.040 - Severability. 
A.  The repeal of ordinances as provided in Section 2 [of Ord. No. 2237] hereof, shall not affect or invalidate any rights acquired, fines, penalties, forfeitures or other liabilities incurred thereunder, or to limit initiation or prosecution of actions involving any of the provisions of said ordinances or parts thereof, and arising out of acts or omissions occurring prior to such repeal. 
B.  If for any reason any chapter, article, section, subsection, sentence, portion or part of the Derby Municipal Code, or the application thereof to any person or circumstances, is declared to be unconstitutional or invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of the code. 
(Ord. No. 2237, §§ 5, 6, 7-14-15) 
Chapter 1.04 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Sections: 

1.04.010 - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, whenever used in the ordinances of the city, shall be construed as defined in this section unless from the context a different meaning is intended or unless a different meaning is specifically defined and more particularly directed to the use of such words or phrases: 
A.  "City" means the city of Derby, Kansas, or the area within the territorial limits of the city of Derby, Kansas, and such territory outside of the city over which the city has jurisdiction or control by virtue of any constitutional or statutory provision. 
B.  "Computation of time" means the time within which an act is to be done. It is computed by excluding the first day and including the last day; and if the last day is Sunday or a legal holiday, that day shall be excluded. 
C.  "Council" means the city council of the city. "All its members" or "all councilmen" means the total number of councilmen provided by the general laws of the state. 
D.  "County" means the county of Sedgwick, Kansas. 
E.  "Law" denotes applicable federal law, the constitution and statutes of the state, the ordinances of the city, and, when appropriate, any and all rules and regulations which may be promulgated thereunder. 
F.  "May" is permissive. 
G.  "Month" means a calendar month. 
H.  "Must" and "shall." Each is mandatory. 
I.  "Oath" includes an affirmation or declaration in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" are equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
J.  "Ordinance" means a law of the city; provided that a temporary or special law, administrative action, order or directive may be in the form of a resolution. 
K.  "Owner," applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety of the whole or a part of such building or land. 
L.  "Person" means natural person, joint venture, joint stock company, partnership, association, club, company, corporation, business, trust or organization or the manager, lessee, agent, servant, officer or employee of any of them. 
M.  "Personal property" includes money, goods, chattels, things in action and evidences of debt. 
N.  "Preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
O.  "Property" includes real and personal property. 
P.  "Real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
Q.  "Sidewalk" means that portion of a street between the curb line and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians. 
R.  "State" means the state of Kansas. 
S.  "Street" includes all streets, highways, avenues, lanes, alleys, courts, places, squares, curbs or other public ways in this city which have been or may hereafter be dedicated and open to public use, or such other public property so designated in any law of this state. 
T.  "Tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, includes any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
U.  Title of Office. Use of the title of any officer, employee, department, board or commission means that officer, employee, department, board or commission of the city. 
V.  "Written" includes printed, typewritten, mimeographed or multigraphed. 
W.  "Year" means a calendar year. 
(Ord. 906 § 1 (part), 1974) 
1.04.020 - Construction of language. 
    All words and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common and approved usage of the language; but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning. 
(Ord. 906 § 1 (part), 1974) 
1.04.030 - Acts by agents. 
    When an act is required by an ordinance, the same being such that it may be done as well by an agent as by the principal, such requirement includes all such acts performed by an authorized agent. 
(Ord. 906 § 1 (part), 1974) 
1.04.040 - Grammatical interpretation. 
    The following grammatical rules apply in the ordinances of the city: 
A.  Gender. The masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter genders. 
B.  Singular and Plural. The singular number includes the plural and the plural includes the singular. 
C.  Tenses. Words used in the present tense include the past and the future tenses and vice versa, unless manifestly inapplicable. 
D.  Use of Words and Phrases. Words and phrases not specifically defined shall be construed according to the context and approved usage of the language. 
(Ord. 906 § 2, 1974) 
1.04.050 - Prohibited acts. 
    Whenever in the ordinances of the city any act or omission is made unlawful, it includes causing, allowing, permitting, aiding, abetting, suffering or concealing the fact of such act or omission. 
(Ord. 906 § 3, 1974) 
1.04.060 - Construction of provisions. 
    The provisions of the ordinances of the city and all proceedings under them are to be construed with a view to effect their objects and to promote justice. 
(Ord. 906 § 4, 1974) 
1.04.070 - Repeal shall not revive any ordinances. 
    The repeal of an ordinance shall not repeal the repealing clause of such ordinance or revive any ordinance which has been repealed thereby. 
(Ord. 906 § 5, 1974) 
Chapter 1.08 - RIGHT OF ENTRY FOR INSPECTION 
Sections: 

1.08.010 - Procedure. 
    Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce any ordinance or resolution, whenever there is reasonable cause to believe there exists an ordinance or resolution violation in any building or upon any premises within jurisdiction of the city, any authorized official of the city may, upon presentation of proper credentials, enter such building or premises at all reasonable times to inspect the same or to perform any duty imposed upon him by ordinance; provided, that except in emergency situations or when consent of the owner and/or occupant to the inspection has been otherwise obtained, he shall give the owner and/or occupant, if they can be located after reasonable effort, twenty-four hours' written notice of the authorized official's intention to inspect. The notice transmitted to the owner and/or occupant shall state that the property owner has the right to refuse entry and that in the event such entry is refused, inspection may be made only upon issuance of a search warrant by a duly authorized magistrate. In the event the owner and/or occupant refuses entry after such request has been made, the official is empowered to seek assistance from any court of competent jurisdiction in obtaining such entry. 
(Ord. 907 § 1, 1974) 
Chapter 1.12 - WARDS[2] 
Sections: 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2097, § 4, adopted November 29, 2011, repealed former Chapter 1.12, §§ 1.12.030-1.12.080, and §§ 1-3 of said ordinance enacted a new Chapter 1.12 as set out herein. The former Chapter 1.12 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 1774, §§ 1, 2, 2003. 

1.12.030. - Division into wards. 
A.  The City of Derby, Kansas shall be divided into four wards, the designations and descriptions of which shall be as follows: 
  Ward Number One. Ward number one shall consist of all that part of the City of Derby, Kansas, described as follows: The area bounded by a line that begins at the intersection of Oliver and 55th Street South, thence southerly along the west city limits to Red Powell Drive, thence west along the city limits along Red Powell extended to the extended centerline of Oliver, thence south along the city limits to the extended centerline of 71st Street South, thence east along the centerline of 71st Street South and along the centerline of Meadowlark Boulevard to the west line of The Oaks Addition, thence north along said west line to the centerline of Tall Tree Road; thence east along Tall Tree Road to Amber Ridge Street as platted in Phillips-Rock Road Addition, thence north and west along the city limits to Rock Road; thence northeast and north along the city limits to 63rd Street South; thence west, south and west along the city limits to Rock Road; thence north along the city limits to north line of Anderson Farm Commercial Addition; thence west along the city limits to Woodlawn, thence south, west, north, east and north along the city limits to 55th Street South, thence west, south, west, north and west along the city limits to point of beginning. 
  Ward Number Two. Ward number two shall consist of all that part of the City of Derby, Kansas, described as follows: The area bounded by a line that begins at the west city limits at the extended centerline of 71st Street South, thence southerly and easterly along the west city limits to McIntosh Road, thence south along the centerline of McIntosh to north line of Derby Industrial Park 2nd Addition, thence east to BNSF Railroad, thence northwesterly to north line of Lance Addition, thence easterly to Nelson Drive, thence southerly along Nelson Drive and easterly along the centerline of Crestway Avenue to Buckner Street, thence north along the centerline of Buckner Street to James Street, thence east along the centerline of James Street to Rock Road, thence south along the centerline of Rock Road to Madison Avenue, thence east along the centerline of Madison Avenue to the east city limits, thence northerly along the east city limits to Meadowlark Boulevard, thence, north, west, north, and west along the city limits to the intersection of Tall Tree Road and Amber Ridge Street as platted in the Phillips-Rock Road Addition, thence west along the centerline of Tall Tree Road to the west line of The Oaks Addition, thence south along west line of The Oaks Addition to Meadowlark, thence west along the centerline of Meadowlark Road and 71st Street South to the point of beginning. 
  Ward Number Three. Ward number three shall consist of all that part of the City of Derby, Kansas described as follows: The area bounded by a line that begins at the intersection of Madison and McIntosh, thence east along the centerline of Madison to Water Street, thence south on Water Street to Cherry Street to Buckner Street; thence north on the centerline of Buckner Avenue to Madison Avenue, thence east on the centerline of Madison Avenue to Derby Street thence south on the centerline of Derby Street to Market Street, thence east along the centerline of Market Street to Willow Street, thence south on the centerline of Willow to Kay Street, thence east along the centerline of Kay Street to Brookwood Drive, thence easterly along the stream centerline of Spring Creek to Rock Road, thence north on the centerline of Rock Road to a point south of Country View Drive, thence easterly and north along the southerly and east boundaries of Springcreek 2nd Addition and along the east line of Springcreek 2nd Addition extended north to Madison Avenue, thence west along the centerline of Madison Avenue to Rock Road thence north along the centerline of Rock Road to James, thence west along the centerline of James Street to Buckner Street, thence south along the centerline of Buckner Street to Crestway Avenue, thence westerly along the centerline of Crestway Avenue to Nelson Drive, thence northerly along Nelson Drive to a point between Crestway Avenue and Greenway Street, thence southwesterly across K-15 to the north line of Lance Addition, thence along north and west lines of Lance Addition to the north line extended to Derby Industrial Park 2nd Addition, thence west to McIntosh, thence south, west, south and east along the city limits to point of beginning, together with that land platted as Quail Run and Quail Run 2nd Additions. 
  Ward Number Four. Ward number four shall consist of all that part of the City of Derby, Kansas as follows: The area bounded by a line that begins at the intersection of Madison and McIntosh, thence southerly, and east along the city limits to Buckner, thence north and east to K-15, thence southerly, easterly, northerly, westerly, northerly, and easterly to Woodlawn Boulevard, thence southerly along the centerline of Woodlawn Boulevard to 91st Street South, thence west along the centerline and centerline extended of 91st Street South across K-15 to the west city limits, thence southerly, easterly, southerly, easterly across K-15 and southerly along the city limits to 95th Street South, thence easterly, north, and east along the city limits to Woodlawn Boulevard, thence north, east, north, east, south and east along the city limits to Rock Road, thence north, east, north, west and north along the city limits to a point between Kay Street and Country View Drive, thence westerly to the intersection of Kay Street and Willow, thence north along the centerline of Willow to Market, thence along the centerline of Market to Derby Street, thence north along centerline of Derby Street to Madison, thence west on centerline of Madison to Buckner thence south on the centerline of Buckner to Cherry Street, thence west on the centerline of Cherry to Water Street, thence north on the centerline of Water Street to Madison, thence west on the centerline of Madison to the point of beginning, together with that land platted as Dove Hollow Addition. 
 All in accordance with the official ward boundary map on file in the office of the city clerk. 
B.  The wards established pursuant to subsection A. hereof shall be depicted on a map prepared by the city and maintained on file in the office of the city clerk provided, that in the event of a conflict between such map and a ward description contained in said subsection A., the map shall control. 
C.  When any territory is annexed to the city of Derby, Kansas, it shall be considered a part of the ward to which it is annexed. 
(Ord. No. 2097, §§ 1-4, 11-29-11) 
Title 2 - ADMINISTRATION AND PERSONNEL* 
Chapters: 
  
* Prior history: Ordinances 446, 476, 501, 580, 582, 649, 665, 666, 741, 790, 809, 852, 867, 871, 884, 930, 941, 977, 992, 1006, 1047, 1050, 1055, 1059, 1075, 1154, 1237, 1238, 1239, 1240, 1242, 1277, 1331, 1414, 1425 and 1455; Charter Ordinances 4, 10, 11, 12, 16, 19, 25, 26 and 30. 
Chapter 2.04 - MAYOR AND COUNCIL 
Sections: 

2.04.010 - Stipends for members of governing body. 
A.  Amount of Stipend. 
1.  The mayor shall, upon his or her election to accept the same, be entitled to receive a stipend of five hundred dollars for each calendar month that he or she holds office, such stipend to be paid monthly. 
2.  Each council member shall, upon his or her election to accept the same, be entitled to receive a stipend of one hundred dollars for each calendar month that he or she holds office, such stipend to be paid monthly. 
B.  In the event the tenure of a member of the governing body begins on a day other than the first day of a month or ends on a day other than the last day of a month, the stipend for such month shall be prorated for the number of days served. 
C.  No stipend shall be payable hereunder to any member of the governing body who does not elect to accept the same; provided, that such member may recommend that a donation equal to the amount of such stipend be made to an organization identified on the city's approved list as contained in the then-current Governing Body Manual of the city of Derby. 
(Ord. No. 1986, § 1, 5-26-09; Ord. No. 2265, § 1, 2-9-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1986, § 2, adopted May 26, 2009, repealed the former § 2.04.010, and enacted a new § 2.04.010 as set out herein. The former § 2.04.010 pertained to the mayor's stipend and derived from Ord. No. 1825, 2005. 
2.04.020 - Day and time of council meetings. 
    The council shall conduct its regular meetings on the second and fourth Tuesday of each month, commencing at six-thirty p.m., and may conduct such additional meetings as it deems appropriate at any time; provided, that when a regular meeting day falls on a day observed as a holiday in the city, such regular meeting shall convene at six-thirty p.m. on the next business day thereafter that is not observed as a holiday or as otherwise previously ordered by the council. 
(Ord. 1942 § 1, 2008) 
2.04.030 - Special meetings. 
    Any special meeting may be called by the mayor on written request of not less than three members of the council addressed to the mayor, specifying the object and purpose of the meetings, which request must be read at the meeting and entered at length on the journal. The call of the mayor for any such meeting shall be issued in such manner as may be required by the rules of the council. (Added during 1996 republication) 
Chapter 2.08 - ORGANIZATION[1] 
Sections: 

Footnotes:

    The mission of the city and the functions and tasks required for accomplishment thereof shall be performed by the following departments:

(Ord. No. 2066, § 1, 4-26-11) 
Chapter 2.12 - COMPENSATION 
Sections: 
Article I. - Wages, Salaries, and Benefits 

2.12.010 - Wages and salaries. 
    The city manager shall be compensated as determined by the council. All other officers and employees of the city shall be compensated pursuant to a pay plan approved by the city council. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
(Ord. No. 2171, § 3, 8-27-13)

    The city council may adopt a personnel policy manual specifying working conditions, job qualifications, benefits, and other matters related to municipal employment; provided, that no such manual shall be construed to constitute a contract between the city and its employees. 
(Added during 1996 republication)

Chapter 2.16 - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 
Sections: 
Article I. - Planning Commission 

2.16.010 - Established. 
    A planning commission for the city is created. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
2.16.020 - Members-Number. 
    The number of members of the planning commission is fixed at ten members. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
2.16.030 - Members-Appointment. 
    The members of the planning commission shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the consent of the city council, in all respects as required by law. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
Article II. - Wichita-Sedgwick County Metropolitan Planning Commission 

2.16.040 - Agreement with county. 
    The city, under the authority of K.S.A. 1965 Supp. 12-716, et seq., ratifies and concurs in the joint ordinance-resolution establishing the Wichita-Sedgwick County metropolitan area planning commission and an agreement dated December 19, 1967, with any amendments thereto, adopted by the board of commissioners of the city of Wichita and the board of commissioners of Sedgwick County. All future agreements or amendments are also ratified and concurred in, provided they are served on the city clerk and the chairman of the city planning commission and provided the governing body does not officially object within thirty days of the service of such notice. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
2.16.050 - Membership established. 
    By action provided in Section 2.16.040, the city establishes itself as a member of the Wichita-Sedgwick County metropolitan area planning commission. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
2.16.060 - Service of copies. 
    The city clerk is directed to serve a copy of the ordinance codified in this chapter to each governing body who is a member of the Wichita-Sedgwick County metropolitan area planning commission and the secretary of the metropolitan area planning commission. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
Article III. - Community Development Advisory Board[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2186, §§ 1, 2, adopted Jan. 14, 2014, repealed former Art. III and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Art. III, §§ 2.16.070-2.16.110 pertained to the economic development board, and derived from Ord. 1847, § 1, adopted in 2006; and Ord. 1872, § 1, adopted in 2006. 

2.16.070 - Created-Members, terms, and appointments. 
A.  Establishment. A board is created to be known as the community development advisory board ("CDAB") which shall be composed of six members. 
B.  Members. Five members of the board shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city council. The sixth member of the board shall be designated by the Derby Chamber of Commerce. All members of the board shall be resident taxpayers of the city or its environs. 
C.  Terms. Upon creation, the CDAB shall be comprised of the remaining membership of the previously existing economic development board and the ordinance review advisory board. The then remaining members of the economic development board appointed by the mayor shall be appointed to the CDAB for an initial term of two years. The remaining members of the ordinance review advisory board shall be appointed to the CDAB for an initial term of one year. At the expiration of the initial terms, all appointees of the mayor shall be thereafter appointed for a term of two years. The Derby Chamber of Commerce designee to the board shall be appointed for a term of one year. 
(Ord. No. 2186, § 1, 1-14-14) 
2.16.080 - Meetings. 
    The CDAB shall meet every other month or more frequently at the call of the chairman or a majority of its members. 
(Ord. No. 2186, § 1, 1-14-14) 
2.16.090 - Officers-Administrative support. 
    The CDAB shall, in the second quarter of each year, elect from its members a chairman and vice-chairman, who shall serve in such capacity for one year. The city manager shall provide appropriate administrative support to the CDAB, including but not limited to recording of meeting minutes, through the designee of his or her choosing. 
(Ord. No. 2186, § 1, 1-14-14) 
2.16.100 - Confidentiality provisions. 
A.  Confidentiality. Upon receipt of an application for a financial incentive for economic development, each member of the CDAB desiring to participate in review and analysis of such application shall execute a confidentiality/nondisclosure agreement to protect the confidentiality of information supplied with respect to such application. The confidentiality/nondisclosure agreement shall provide for the confidentiality of the applicant's financial information, customer information, product development information, trade secrets and other information which, if disclosed, could reasonably be expected to harm the applicant's business. Any CDAB member who does not execute a confidentiality/nondisclosure agreement promptly upon presentation shall neither have access to documents, records, and information relating to such application nor participate in analysis or development of recommendations with respect to such application. Breach of a confidentiality/nondisclosure agreement by any member of the CDAB shall be cause for removal of such member from the CDAB. 
B.  Public Records. Neither the CDAB nor any of its members shall have authority to grant access to records pursuant to the Kansas Open Records Act. All requests for access to or copying of records in the possession of the city shall be referred to the records custodian pursuant to the city's open records policy. 
(Ord. No. 2186, § 1, 1-14-14) 
2.16.110 - Mission-Relationship to city council. 
A.  The primary mission of the board shall be to monitor and maintain the city's economic development plan; make recommendations to the city council on development projects for which city incentives are requested; propose changes to policies governing economic development activities; and advocate for programs and activities that will improve the city's economic conditions. 
B.  The CDAB shall also review, comment on, and make recommendations to the city council with respect to current or proposed ordinances of general applicability. 
C.  The board shall be advisory to the city council and shall make its recommendations to the council through the city manager or designee. 
(Ord. No. 2186, § 1, 1-14-14) 
Article IV. - Parks and Urban Forestry Board 

2.16.120 - Creation of parks and urban forestry board-Appointment and terms of members-Procedures. 
A.  There is hereby created a parks and urban forestry board (the "board") consisting of seven members. The mayor, by and with the consent of the city council, shall appoint the members of the board, who shall serve without compensation. The members shall be residents of the city. The city shall provide guidance through a staff liaison and an administrative assistant, whose function shall be to take the minutes of the meetings. 
B.  Upon creation of the board, three members shall be appointed for a term of two years and four members shall be appointed for a term of three years. At the expiration of the initial terms, all members shall be thereafter appointed for a term of two years. In the event a vacancy occurs during the term of any member, a successor shall be appointed in like manner for the unexpired portion of the term. 
C.  The board shall make an annual report of its proceedings to the governing body, to include the condition of the parks of the city and the planting, maintenance, treatment, and removal of trees and shrubbery located on streets, alleys, avenues, boulevards and public rights-of-way within the city. 
D.  The board shall choose its own officers, make its own procedural rules and regulations and keep minutes of its proceedings; provided, that any procedural rules and regulations established by the board shall be subject to review and modification by the city council. A majority of all members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. 1849 § 1, 2006) 
2.16.125 - Duties of board. 
A.  The board shall: 
1.  Develop a list of goals and objectives, to include needs and usage of the existing parks and open space; needs for additional park grounds; the size and types of park grounds to be considered; development of short and long range capital improvements required to develop current and proposed park grounds; and essential environmental concerns for the community and the surrounding planning and growth area; 
2.  Develop a plan for the care of street and park trees, including their planting, culture, and removal or disposition; 
3.  In conjunction with the Derby recreation commission ("DRC") and interested groups or individuals, develop programs and review existing programs to encourage the usage of city parks and open space. When feasible, such programs should provide for joint use of land with other governmental entities to include the DRC and USD 260; 
4.  Develop initiatives to enhance the image of the community, both at the neighborhood level and city-wide, through beautification and preservation projects to include landscaping, tree planting, decorative lighting, and measures to reduce traffic, noise, sight and other types of pollution. 
B.  The board shall meet at least once each month and shall make its recommendations to the city council in writing at least six days prior to the next regularly scheduled city council meeting. 
(Ord. 1849 § 2, 2006) 
2.16.130 - Tree species, spacing and location regulations. 
A.  The city shall maintain a list of recommended tree species for planting on public property. Such list shall be available to residents of the city upon request to aid in the selection of trees for private properties. The list shall be updated annually by the board to reflect new developments or species which have favorable characteristics for inclusion in the community forest. 
B.  Street trees may be planted no closer together than thirty feet except in special plantings approved by the director of public works and parks (the "director"). 
C.  Street trees may be planted in the sidestrip where there is more than six feet between the edge of the sidewalk and the curb of the street. Street trees shall be planted no closer than three feet from a sidewalk or a street. 
D.  No street tree shall be planted closer than thirty-five feet from any street corner, measured from the point of the nearest intersection of curbs or curb lines. 
E.  No street tree shall be planted closer than ten feet from any fire hydrant. 
F.  No street tree shall be planted within ten feet of any point on a line on the ground immediately below any overhead utility wire, or within five lateral feet of any ground immediately below any overhead utility, without the express written consent of the director. 
(Ord. 1849 § 3, 2006) 
2.16.135 - Care of community and city-owned property. 
A.  The city may, at its discretion, plant, prune, maintain, and remove trees, plants, and shrubs within all rights-of-way, public easements, streets, alleys, lanes, squares, and public grounds, as may be necessary to insure the public safety or to preserve or enhance the beauty of such public grounds. 
B.  The board may request that the director remove any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines, or other public improvements, or is seriously affected by injurious insects or disease. 
C.  An abutting property owner shall have the right to perform normal tree care on street trees in conformity with this chapter and any other applicable regulations. 
(Ord. 1849 § 4, 2006) 
2.16.140 - Tree topping. 
    It is unlawful for any person, to top any street tree, park tree, or other tree on public property; provided, that trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, and trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical, may be topped when authorized by the director. 
(Ord. 1849 § 5, 2006) 
2.16.145 - Clearance over streets and walkways. 
    Maintenance of adequate clearance over street and walkways shall be the responsibility of the abutting property owner. A clearance of eight feet must be maintained over walkways and a clearance of twelve feet must be maintained over streets. Property owners are responsible for trees on their own property as well as street trees on public ways abutting their property. 
(Ord. 1849 § 6, 2006) 
2.16.150 - Removal of dead or diseased trees. 
    The city may remove, or cause to be removed, any damaged, dead or diseased tree within the city limits, and may recover the cost thereof from the owner of the property upon which the same is located, all in accordance with the procedures established in K.S.A. 12-3201 et seq., and amendments thereto, or pursuant to any other procedure provided by law. Upon removal of a public tree, the stump shall be removed below the surface of the ground. 
(Ord. 1849 § 7, 2006) 
2.16.155 - Interference with community and city-owned property. 
    It is unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the city or any of its representatives or agents while engaged in planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying, or removing any tree within the community forest, or performing any other duties or responsibilities prescribed by this chapter. 
(Ord. 1849 § 8, 2006) 
2.16.160 - Arborist-License required. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or occupation of planting, pruning, treating or removing any tree, whether located on public or private property, without first applying for and securing a license from the city. The license fee shall be fixed by the city council. 
B.  Any firm engaged in the business of planting, trimming, pruning, treating, or removing street or park trees within the city shall have liability insurance in the minimum amounts of five hundred thousand dollars for bodily injury and five hundred thousand dollars for property damage, indemnifying the city or any person injured or damaged as a result of such activities. 
C.  The board shall make recommendations to the city council in regard to licensing requirements and fees. 
(Ord. 1849 § 9, 2006) 
2.16.165 - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars, imprisonment not to exceed thirty days, or to both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. 1849 § 10, 2006) 
2.16.170 - Unconstitutionality. 
    If any portion of this chapter is found to be unconstitutional, then only that portion shall be declared void; the remainder of this chapter shall remain in full force and effect as though the portion invalidated had not been adopted. 
(Ord. 1849 § 11, 2006) 
Article V. - Public Building Commission 

2.16.180 - Creation. 
    There is hereby created by the council, under the authority of the Act, a municipal corporation to be known as the city of Derby, Kansas public building commission (the "PBC"). 
(Ord. 1622 § 1, 1998) 
2.16.190 - Composition. 
A.  The PBC shall be composed of five members (the "members"). All members shall be appointed by the council. One member shall be appointed as a representative of Unified School District No. 260 (the "school district representative"), and one shall be appointed from the council membership (the "council representative"). The remaining three members shall be residents of the city. 
B.  The council representative shall serve at the pleasure of the council. Two members (including the school district representative) shall have an initial term expiring on December 31, 1999, and the two remaining members shall have an initial term expiring on December 31, 2000. The term of office for members, other than the council representative, after the expiration of the initial term, shall be two years. 
C.  In the event that the PBC provides buildings or structures that are leased to governmental entities other than the city, the composition of the PBC shall be modified, if and to the extent necessary to conform to the requirements of the Act, by adoption of an appropriate ordinance. 
(Ord. 1622 § 2, 1998: Ord. 1659 § 1, 1999) 
2.16.200 - Purpose, powers and functions. 
    The PBC is created for the purposes of, and shall have the powers and shall perform the functions set forth in, the Act and the charter ordinance, as amended from time to time by statute or charter ordinance. The council, by subsequent ordinance, shall have the authority to limit the purposes, powers and/or functions of the PBC. 
(Ord. 1622 § 3, 1998) 
2.16.210 - Support services. 
    Unless otherwise approved by the council, the city manager and other city staff will provide administrative services to the PBC, the city's bond counsel and the city attorney shall provide legal services to the PBC and the city's financial advisor shall provide financial advisory services to the PBC. 
(Ord. 1622 § 4, 1998) 
2.16.220 - Further action. 
    The PBC shall have the authority to adopt bylaws and resolutions or take other official actions not inconsistent with the provisions of this article, the charter ordinance and the Act. 
(Ord. 1622 § 5, 1998) 
Article VII. - Americans with Disabilities Act Advisory Board 

2.16.280 - Creation. 
    There is created and established an Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) advisory board (the "board") for the city of Derby, Kansas, which shall be composed of six members. Board members shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city council. At least three of the six members shall have a disability, have provided care to someone with a disability, or be representatives of organizations that provide services to people with disabilities. 
(Ord. 1853 § 1, 2006) 
(Ord. No. 2210, § 1, 10-28-14; Ord. No 2342, § 1, 1-9-18) 
2.16.290 - Members-Appointment. 
    Upon its creation, three members of the board shall be appointed for a term of two years, and three members shall be appointed for a term of one year. At the expiration of the initial terms, all board members shall be thereafter appointed for a term of two years. 
(Ord. 1853 § 2, 2006) 
2.16.300 - Members-Term. 
    The board shall upon its creation and in May of each year thereafter, elect from its members a chairman and vice-chairman, who shall serve in such capacity for one year. The city manager shall provide appropriate administrative support to the ADA advisory board, including but not limited to recording of meeting minutes. 
(Ord. 1853 § 3, 2006) 
2.16.310 - Meetings. 
    The board shall meet quarterly or more frequently at the call of the chairman or a majority of members. 
(Ord. 1853 § 4, 2006) 
(Ord. No. 2210, § 2, 10-28-14) 
2.16.320 - Mission-Relationship to city council. 
A.  The mission of the board shall be to work towards full compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act with respect to all city facilities and activities, including but not limited to identifying problems with program accessibility; establishing timelines for ADA improvements to be made; and advocating for improvements that will increase the city's ADA accessibility. 
B.  The board will be advisory to the city council and will make its suggestions and recommendations to the council through the city's ADA coordinator. 
(Ord. 1853 § 5, 2006) 
Article VIII. - Youth Advisory Board 

2.16.330 - Creation of youth advisory board. 
    A board is created, to be known as the youth advisory board ("YAB"). All YAB members shall be enrolled at Derby High School and residents of Unified School District No. 260. The YAB shall be composed of twelve members. The presidents of the freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior classes shall be ex officio members with full voice and vote. The remaining members shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the governing body and shall include one member of Student Council; one DECA member; one Youth Leadership Council member; one student athlete; two members representing other student organizations; and two members appointed at-large. 
(Ord. 1895 § 1, 2007) 
2.16.340 - Members-Terms. 
    Members shall be appointed for a term of one year upon commencement of the USD 260 fall semester. 
(Ord. 1895 § 2, 2007) 
2.16.350 - Officers-Administrative support. 
    Annually in September, the YAB shall elect from its members a chairperson who shall serve in such capacity for one year. The city manager shall provide appropriate administrative support to the YAB. 
(Ord. 1895 § 3, 2007) 
2.16.360 - Meetings. 
    The YAB shall meet monthly or more frequently at the call of the chairperson or a majority of its members. 
(Ord. 1895 § 4, 2007) 
2.16.370 - Mission-Relationship to the city council. 
A.  The mission of the YAB shall be to cultivate the link between the city council and the youth of Derby by identifying and responding to issues pertaining to youth; accurately communicate the concerns of youth, and respectfully recommend actions to be taken; promote service to the community; and seek to engage teens in community activities so that youth move through their teen years connected to their community. 
B.  The YAB will be advisory to the city council and will forward its suggestions and recommendations to the city council through the city manager. 
(Ord. 1895 § 5, 2007) 
Article IX. - Senior Services Advisory Board 

2.16.380 - Creation of senior services advisory board; eligibility for membership. 
    A board is hereby created, to be known as the senior services advisory board (the "board"). The board shall be composed of seven members appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city council. Board members shall be residents of the city and removal of a board member from the city shall automatically vacate such member's office. 
(Ord. No. 1937, § 1, 5-27-08) 
2.16.390 - Members; terms. 
    Current board members appointed to a term of four years in 2010 shall serve until 2014. The four-year terms of current board members appointed in 2012 shall be modified to three-year terms, and those members shall serve until 2015. Thereafter, each member shall be appointed for a term of two years or until a successor is appointed and qualified. Appointments made to fill vacancies on the board shall be for the unexpired term of the original appointment. 
(Ord. No. 1937, § 2, 5-27-08; Ord. No. 2154, § 1, 5-14-13) 
2.16.400 - Officers; administrative support. 
    Upon its creation and annually thereafter in May, the board shall elect from its members a chair and vice-chair who serve in such capacities for one year. The city manager shall provide appropriate administrative support to the board through the designee of his or her choosing. 
(Ord. No. 1937, § 3, 5-27-08) 
2.16.410 - Meetings. 
    The board shall meet monthly or more frequently at the call of the chairman or a majority of its members. 
(Ord. No. 1937, § 4, 5-27-08) 
2.16.420 - Mission; relationship to city council. 
A.  The mission of the board shall be to comment on and make recommendations to the city council with respect to the social, health, educational, nutritional, physical, recreational, and intellectual well being of the senior citizens of the city of Derby. 
B.  The board will be advisory to the city council and will forward its suggestions and recommendations to the council through the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 1937, § 5, 5-27-08) 
Article X. - Removal 

2.16.430 - Removal of any board or commission member. 
A.  Members of any board or commission may be removed by the mayor for any of the following reasons: 
1.  Committing any act constituting a felony; or 
2.  Committing any act constituting a violation of any penal statute involving moral turpitude. 
B.  A majority of the city council may remove any member of any board or commission at any time for the following reasons: 
1.  Misconduct in office; 
2.  Failure to perform duties as prescribed by law; 
3.  For such other good and sufficient cause so deemed by the city council. Cause shall include, but not be limited to, violations of any conflict of interest policy or law; neglect of duty; violation of any applicable law, regulation or policy; excessive unexcused non-attendance at meetings; or conduct which raises questions concerning the city's business practices or impartiality. 
C.  Notice of the city council meeting and an opportunity to be present and be heard at the time and place scheduled for said meeting shall be provided to any board or commission member for whom removal is being considered under the provisions of subsection B. 
(Ord. No. 2240, § 1, 8-25-15) 
Chapter 2.20 - OPEN PUBLIC RECORDS 
Sections: 

2.20.010 - Public access requests. 
    All members of the public, in seeking access to, or copies of, a public record in accordance with the provisions of the Kansas Open Records Act, shall address their requests to the record custodian. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
2.20.020 - Record custodian-Appointment. 
    The city clerk is appointed as official custodian for purposes of the Kansas Open Records Act, K.S.A. 1983 Supp. 45-201;214, and is charged with responsibility for compliance with that Act with respect to all public records. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
2.20.030 - Record custodian-Duties generally. 
    The record custodian shall: protect public records from damage and disorganization; prevent excessive disruption of the essential functions of the city; provide assistance and information upon request; insure efficient and timely action and response to all applications for inspection of public records; and shall carry out the procedures adopted by this city for inspecting and copying open public records. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
2.20.040 - Procedure-Generally. 
    The following procedures are adopted and shall be applied by the record custodian: 
A.  Consistent with the policy, duties and procedures established by the state of Kansas in K.S.A. 1983 Supp. 45-205;214 the city record custodian shall provide full access and assistance in a timely and efficient manner to persons who request access to open public records. 
B.  The record custodian shall adopt and apply open public record access and copy procedures consistent with the policies of the city and with the provisions of the Open Records Act. Specifically, such procedures will inform members of the public of the procedures to be followed in making a request for inspection or a copy of an open public record, including the hours during which record inspection or copy requests may be made; who a request is to be made to; the forms to be completed in making a request; and the schedule of fees charged. 
C.  The record custodian shall adopt and apply procedures which will ensure the protection and preservation of public records with respect to the manner in which such records are inspected and copied. 
D.  The record custodian shall take necessary measures not inconsistent with his/her duties, to provide full public access to open public records, to ensure that the essential functions of the city office, department or agency is not disrupted by requests for record inspection and copying. 
E.  All inspections and copying of open public records shall be performed by, or under the supervision of, the record custodian. 
F.  All persons requesting the inspection of or a copy of open public records shall make such request in writing prior to the request being honored, except that no form shall be required for requests made for records which have been reproduced for free public distribution. 
G.  All record inspection and copying forms are to be completed by the person requesting the record. The record custodian may demand reasonable identification of any person requesting a record. 
H.  Any fees for record inspection or for copies are due at the time the records, or copies thereof, are provided to the requester, unless the record custodian has demanded that prepayment of all or part of such fees be made. 
I.  The record custodian shall notify the record requester, prior to commencing search of the record or copies thereof, of his or her estimate of the fee which will be made for honoring the request whenever such estimate exceeds five dollars. 
J.  The record custodian shall demand full or partial prepayment of fees whenever his or her estimate for such fees exceeds twenty dollars. Prepayment may or may not be required of a requester who maintains an account in good standing with the city for purposes of payment of record fees. 
K.  The record custodian shall determine and assess a charge covering mailing and handling costs accrued in responding to requests through the mail service. 
L.  The record custodian may exercise his or her discretion to reduce or waive any inspection or copying fees when such is in the public interest. 
M.  No record inspection or copying charge shall be assessed against officers or employees of the city who make requests which are reasonably necessary to the performance of their official duties. 
N.  Hours for making requests for inspection or copying shall be all regular working hours for each day the office maintains regular office hours. 
O.  Removal of open public records from the office where kept and maintained, for purposes of inspection and/or the making of copies shall be permitted only with the written permission of the record custodian. It is unlawful for any person to fail to return such records at the time and place where such return has been promised. Upon conviction for violation of this subsection a person may be fined up to five hundred dollars or sentenced to thirty days in the jail, or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
P.  The above procedures, as well as any other inspection and copying procedures shall be posted in a conspicuous place in the office of the record custodian. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
2.20.050 - Procedure-Records inspection. 
    The following procedures are adopted and shall be applied by the official record custodians: 
A.  The record custodian shall handle all inspection requests in accordance with his/her duties to protect and preserve public records and to assist persons requesting inspection of open public records. 
B.  All request forms must be completed by the party requesting the record. In all cases the party so requesting must be an individual person or persons. Written requests shall be made on the form provided by the record custodian and presented to the record custodian. 
C.  A written request is sufficient if it reasonably describes the record sought. In instances where the requester cannot provide sufficient information to identify a record, the custodian shall assist in making such identification. 
D.  In cases where a request for a specific record gives the record custodian reason to believe that the record contains information of a personal nature which if disclosed would constitute an unwarranted invasion of personal privacy, the record custodian shall inform the requester that a seventy-two-hour waiting period must run before such record may be inspected. During that seventy-two-hour period, the record custodian shall make very reasonable effort to determine the identity of those persons whose privacy interest may be so affected by disclosure. The record custodian shall attempt to contact such persons and ascertain whether they, or any of them, will seek a court order challenging disclosure. If so, the record custodian shall deny inspection pending the outcome of litigation or an intervening court order. 
E.  No inspection fee shall be charged the requester if the actual cost of locating the records pursuant to one request is less than one dollar or, in the case of multiple requests brought by the same person or on behalf of the same person, where the actual cost of locating the records pursuant to requests made over a twenty-four-hour period is less than one dollar. 
F.  No inspection fee will be assessed when a denial of a request is made. The record custodian shall, upon making a denial of an inspection request, forward a copy of the denial to the city attorney. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
2.20.060 - Procedure-Copying. 
    The following procedures are adopted and shall be applied by the official record custodian: 
A.  The record custodian shall handle all copy requests in accordance with his/her duties to protect and preserve public records and to assist persons requesting copies of open public records. 
B.  All request forms must be completed by the party requesting the copies. In all cases the party so requesting must be an individual person or persons. Written requests shall be made on the form provided by the record custodian. 
C.  Mechanical reproduction of a record shall not be undertaken when it is the judgment of the record custodian that any available means of mechanically reproducing the subject record is likely to cause damage to such record. 
D.  No copy fee shall be assessed when multiple copies of the record requested have been prepared for free public distribution, or when the record custodian determines that the cost of charging and handling the fee exceeds the cost of providing a copy without charge. 
E.  No copying fee will be assessed when a denial of a request is made. The record custodian shall, upon making a denial of a copying request, forward a copy of the denial to the city attorney. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
2.20.070 - Fees-Required-Purpose. 
    It is policy of the city to require persons seeking to inspect or copy public records to bear the costs associated therewith, and so to avoid the necessity of using general public funds of the city to subsidize special services and benefits to a record requester. The official record custodian shall periodically recommend to the governing body such changes in the fees charged for inspection and copying of public records as may be necessary to secure this purpose. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
2.20.080 - Fees-Records inspection. 
A.  Where request has been made for inspection of any open public record which is readily available to the record custodian, there shall be no inspection fee charged to the requester. 
B.  In all cases not covered by subsection A of this section, a record inspection fee shall be charged at a rate or rates established by resolution of the governing body. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
2.20.090 - Fees-Copying. 
    The fees to be charged for photocopying of public records shall be established by resolution of the governing body. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
2.20.100 - Fees-Prepayment requirements. 
A.  A record custodian may demand prepayment of the fees established for inspection or copying of public records whenever he or she believes this to be in the best interest of the city. The prepayment amount shall be an estimate of the inspection and/or copying charges accrued in fulfilling the record request. Any overage or underage in the prepayment shall be settled prior to inspection of the requested record or delivery of the requested copies. 
B.  Prepayment of inspection and/or copying fees shall be required whenever, in the best estimate of the record custodian, such fees are estimated to exceed twenty dollars. 
C.  Where prepayment has been demanded by the record custodian, no record shall be made available to the requester until such prepayment has been made. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
2.20.110 - Fees-Payment. 
    All fees charged for inspection or copying of public records shall be paid to the office of the city clerk payable to the city of Derby. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
Title 3 - REVENUE AND FINANCE* 
Chapters: 
Chapter 3.08 - NEWLY ANNEXED PROPERTY-CONTRIBUTION FOR EXISTING SERVICES 
Sections: 

3.08.010 - Assessment of improvements cost. 
    When owners of property adjacent to the city request that the property be platted and annexed to the city, and prior to that time the city has constructed public improvements such as streets or sewer facilities which are available to the land that is to be annexed, and the land has not paid any of its proportionate share of the costs of such construction, the city may assess a charge in the amount of the reasonable value of the public improvements to the property to be annexed. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
3.08.020 - Cost determination-Land dedication option. 
    The exact costs to the land to be annexed shall be determined by the governing body; provided, that in lieu of paying such moneys, as provided in Section 3.08.010, the governing body may require, at its option, the dedication of easements or park areas. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
Chapter 3.13 - SALE OF PROPERTY IN POLICE POSSESSION 

3.13.010 - Scope and disposition of property in general. 
    Any property acquired, delivered, or surrendered to the police department and classified in accordance with police department procedures as unclaimed or for which an owner or person entitled to the property cannot be ascertained shall be kept for a minimum of ninety days. If, after ninety days, the legal owner or person entitled to possession of property cannot be located, or indicates he/she does not wish to have the property returned, the property shall either be sold at auction or destroyed. Proceeds of the sale shall be paid to the city general fund. 
(Ord. No. 2151, § 1, 3-12-13) 
3.13.020 - Disposition of specific property; exceptions. 
    The following types of specific property shall be disposed of as follows: 
A.  Money shall be deposited in the city general fund unless the money is determined to have value as a collector's item. If money is determined to have value as a collector's item, the money shall be sold at public auction and the proceeds of the sale shall be paid to the city general fund. 
B.  Firearms shall be: 
1.  Destroyed; or 
2.  Forfeited to the police department for use within the department; or 
3.  Forfeited to the Kansas Bureau of Investigation for law enforcement testing, comparison, or destruction by the Kansas Bureau of Investigation forensic laboratory. 
C.  Ammunition not retained for police department use shall be destroyed. 
D.  Notwithstanding the provisions of Section 3.13.010, hazardous materials, illegal weapons, alcoholic beverages, medicine or prescription drugs, and contraband may be lawfully destroyed. The term "hazardous materials" means any substance capable of posing an unreasonable risk to health, safety and property. It shall include any substance which by its nature is explosive, flammable, corrosive, poisonous, radioactive, a biological hazard or a material which may cause spontaneous combustion. It shall include but is not limited to substances listed in the table of hazardous materials contained in the Code of Federal Regulations Title 49 and National Fire Protection Association's fire protection guide on hazardous materials. 
E.  Notwithstanding the provisions of Section 3.13.010, sealed, undamaged food products in original packaging and within the "use by" date may be destroyed or donated to a social service agency or charitable organization. 
(Ord. No. 2151, § 2, 3-12-13) 
3.13.030 - Efforts to locate owner. 
    The police department shall be required to make reasonable efforts to locate the owner of property, but the responsibility of identifying and claiming property rests with the owner of the property or the person entitled to the property. A finder of property will be notified by letter that the found property has not been claimed after the ninety-day time period. 
(Ord. No. 2151, § 3, 3-12-13) 
3.13.040 - Claiming property; proof of ownership. 
    Claimants of property shall be required to present reasonable proof of ownership of or entitlement to the property. Reasonable proof of ownership or entitlement may depend upon the property being claimed and the circumstances of its possession by the police department. 
(Ord. No. 2151, § 4, 3-12-13) 
3.13.050 - Auction. 
    The police department is authorized to sell unclaimed property at public auction or by use of an online auction website at the best price possible. 
(Ord. No. 2151, § 5, 3-12-13) 
Chapter 3.16 - INVESTMENT OF CITY FUNDS 
Sections: 

3.16.010 - Investment authorization. 
    The city treasurer is authorized to invest funds of the city, not immediately required for the purposes for which the funds were collected or received, in any investment authorized by or pursuant to Kansas law; provided, that the city treasurer shall keep sufficient funds on hand at all times to pay the obligations of the city as the same become due and owing. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
3.16.020 - Deposit of revenue. 
    All revenue received from the investment of city funds shall be deposited in the general operating fund of the city. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
Chapter 3.44 - SALES TAX REVENUE EXPENDITURES 
Sections: 

3.44.010 - Pledge of certain sales tax revenues. 
    The governing body of the city pledges one-half of any revenue received from the city's portion of a one-percent sales tax to relieve the tax levies of the city upon the taxable tangible property within the city, and pledges the remaining one-half of such revenues to city road, highway and bridge projects, including right-of-way acquisitions. Each year the city budget will be amended to reduce the property tax requirement by one-half of the projected sales tax receipts. The remaining one-half of the projected sales tax receipts will be added to funds for road, highway and bridge projects including right-of-way acquisitions. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
3.44.020 - Intent. 
    It is the specific intent of the governing body of the city that the city continue to use the tax revenues as outlined in this chapter and that this pledge be continued as a matter of faith and trust between the people and the present and future governing bodies of the city. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
Chapter 3.48 - FEE SCHEDULES FOR MUNICIPAL REGULATORY FUNCTIONS 
Sections: 

3.48.010 - Schedules-Authorization-Adoption by resolution. 
    The governing body of the city is authorized to adopt by resolution, and to amend from time to time, one or more schedules of fees and charges to be imposed in connection with the discharge of municipal regulatory functions and provision of municipal services by officers, employees or agents of the city. 
(Ord. 1570 § 1, 1997) 
3.48.020 - Violation-Penalty. 
    It is unlawful for any person to fail or refuse, upon demand therefor, to pay a fee or charge properly established pursuant to this chapter or any other ordinance of the city or provision of the Derby Municipal Code. Violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 1570 § 2, 1997) 
3.48.030 - Repeal of prior fees for same or substantially identical function or service. 
    Upon adoption by resolution of a schedule of fees or charges for one or more regulatory functions or services, each and every provision of a city ordinance or of the Derby Municipal Code which establishes a fee or charge for the same or a substantially identical function or service shall be deemed repealed. Such repealer shall apply only to the fees or charges so established; all other provisions of affected ordinances or sections of the Derby Municipal Code shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. 1570 § 3, 1997) 
Title 5 - BUSINESS LICENSES AND REGULATIONS* 
Chapters: 
Chapter 5.04 - BUSINESS REGISTRATION 
Sections: 

5.04.010 - Fee. 
A.  Every person now or hereafter doing business in the city limits shall register yearly with the city and pay to the city an annual registration fee as established by resolution of the governing body of the city; provided, that businesses which are otherwise licensed by the city are exempt from the registration fee, but must comply with the registration requirements hereof. 
B.  For the purposes of this chapter, "person" means an individual, corporation, partnership, company, agency, institution, or any other association of persons. 
C.  For purposes of this chapter, "doing business in the city limits" shall mean doing any of the following within the corporate city limits of the city of Derby, Kansas: 
1.  Engaging in or conducting business transactions; or 
2.  Maintaining an office; or 
3.  Maintaining a retail or wholesale outlet; or 
4.  Maintaining a business address. 
(Amended during Supp. No. 1, 11/03; Ord. 1570 (part), 1997; added during 1996 republication) 
(Ord. No. 2189, § 1, 2-25-14) 
5.04.020 - Application. 
    Every person required to register a business under this chapter shall, before the initial registration thereof, furnish to the city the following information on a form provided for that purpose: 
A.  Nature of the business; 
B.  Location of the business and zoning of site; 
C.  Business contact information; 
D.  Contact information of owner, manager and key staff; 
E.  Approximate square footage of floor space in the business; 
F.  Approximate number of employees employed in the business. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
(Ord. No. 2189, § 2, 2-25-14) 
5.04.030 - Exemptions. 
    The following businesses shall be exempt from the application of this chapter: door to door peddlers, vendors operating within the city pursuant to a valid temporary use permit, newspaper delivery persons, tax-exempt charitable organizations not maintaining a fixed storefront operation, and public utilities holding franchises from the city which provide for a fixed charge based upon percentage of gross receipts. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
(Ord. No. 2189, § 3, 2-25-14) 
5.04.040 - Posting of certificate. 
    The city shall issue a registration certificate to each business, occupation or profession registered hereunder. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
(Ord. No. 2189, § 4, 2-25-14) 
5.04.050 - Nontransferable-Term-Delinquency penalty. 
    Registrations under this chapter shall be nontransferable. Each registration shall be valid from the date of issue until December 31st next following. Registration fees under this chapter shall not be prorated. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
5.04.060 - Prohibitions. 
    No person shall register a business under this chapter or operate a business which is or will be in violation of any zoning regulations or other ordinances of the city. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
(Ord. No. 2189, § 5, 2-25-14) 
5.04.070 - Failure to register. 
    No person shall commence any business, occupation or profession for which registration is required under this chapter unless such person has first registered with the city as provided in this chapter. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
5.04.080 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person found guilty of a violation of this chapter shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
(Ord. No. 2189, § 6, 2-25-14) 
Chapter 5.06 - CITY PROPERTY USE PERMIT 
Sections: 

5.06.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, unless the context requires otherwise: 
    "Business venture" means the sale or other conveyance of goods, or the performance of services, for compensation in any form. 
    "City property" means any real or personal property owned by or under the control of the city. 
    "Person" means an individual, corporation, partnership, company, agency, institution or any other association of persons. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
5.06.020 - Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to use city property for any business venture without first applying for and securing from the city a permit for such business venture, and entering into an agreement therefor upon such terms and conditions as shall be prescribed by the city. 
(Added during 1996 republication) 
5.06.030 - Penalty.
