    The city may remove, or cause to be removed, any damaged, dead or diseased tree within the city limits, and may recover the cost thereof from the owner of the property upon which the same is located, all in accordance with the procedures established in K.S.A. 12-3201 et seq., and amendments thereto, or through any other means provided by law. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.28.090 - Removal of stumps. 
    Upon removal of a street or park tree, the stump shall be removed below the surface of the ground. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.28.100 - Interference with community forest duties. 
    It is unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the city or any of its representatives or agents while engaged in planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying or removing any tree within the community forest, or performing any other duties or responsibilities prescribed by this chapter. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.28.110 - Arborist-License required. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or occupation of planting, pruning, treating or removing any tree, whether located on public or private property, without first applying for and securing a license from the city. The license fee shall be fixed by the city council. 
B.  Any firm engaged in the business of planting, trimming, pruning, treating or removing street or park trees within the city shall have liability insurance in the minimum amounts of five hundred thousand dollars for bodily injury and five hundred thousand dollars property damage, indemnifying the city or any person injured or damaged as a result of such activities. 
C.  The tree board may make recommendations to the city council in regard to licensing requirements and fees. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.28.120 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction or a plea of guilty, be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars, or to equivalent community service. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
Chapter 12.32 - UNDERGROUND SPRINKLER SYSTEMS ON STATE HIGHWAY RIGHT-OF-WAY 
Sections: 

12.32.010 - Permit required. 
    It is unlawful to excavate, construct or install an underground sprinkler or irrigation system on public right-of-way located within the city and owned by or under the control of the state of Kansas or any agency thereof without first obtaining a permit from the city. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.32.020 - Permit-Application. 
A.  An application for a sprinkler permit shall be made on a form provided by the city and shall be accompanied by a drawing plan or photograph of the proposed improvement. The application shall release the city, the Kansas Department of Transportation (KDOT), and any franchise holder of the city from and indemnify each of them against any and all damages which may be caused to any of them by reason of installation of such sprinkler system in the public right-of-way. 
B.  Construction of such sprinkler systems shall comply with all applicable city codes and standards and with any other requirements prescribed by the city. 
C.  No permit shall be issued hereunder unless the application therefor is first reviewed and approved by the Kansas Department of Transportation (KDOT). Any such application shall, when made by the owner of commercial or industrial property, be accompanied by a certificate of insurance naming the city and the Kansas Department of Transportation as additional insureds. 
D.  Each permit issued hereunder shall specify the location by address and shall authorize excavation, installation and operation of the system in conformity with the approved plan, subject at all times to inspection by the city to determine compliance with city codes, standards and other requirements. 
E.  Approval and disapproval of applications for permits hereunder shall be the responsibility of the director of community safety or his/her duly authorized agent. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.32.030 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall upon conviction be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars, imprisonment for a period not to exceed one month, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.32.040 - Liability for damage. 
    The city shall not be liable to the owner/operator of any underground sprinkler or irrigation system for any damage, except such damage as is caused by gross or wanton negligence, to that portion of such system located on public right-of-way when such damage results in whole or in part from construction, reconstruction, repair or maintenance, including snow removal and other street maintenance work, performed by city forces. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
Chapter 12.36 - EROSION CONTROL 
Sections: 

12.36.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "City manager" means the city manager of the city of Derby, and any other person designated by the city manager to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
    "Contractor" means a construction, building or building trades contractor licensed as such by the city, and any person or firm conducting or performing work for which either a contractor's license or a building permit is required by city ordinance. 
    "Public street" means the entire width of any public street, alley or highway, and shall include gutters, open ditches, catch basins or other drainage structures associated therewith. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.36.020 - Accumulation of material in public streets due to erosion declared nuisance. 
    The accumulation of dirt, sand and other material in public streets as a result of erosion of adjacent real property, to an extent that such material presents a danger to motorists or pedestrian or threatens the integrity of streets, drainageways or other public improvements, as determined by the city manager or his or her designee, is declared to be a nuisance. The owner of or the contractor responsible for any real property from which any such material originated shall remove the same from the public street forthwith, with or without notice from the city. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.36.030 - Notice to owner. 
    When the city manager determines that any dirt, sand or other material accumulated in a public street constitutes a nuisance hereunder, he or she shall ascertain the real property or properties from which such material originated. In addition to any other remedy provided for in this chapter and Chapter 15.36, the manager shall by written notice direct the owner or owners of such property or properties to remove such material from the public street within a reasonable time as set forth in the notice. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.36.040 - Affidavit of notice. 
    Any notice required to be given to an owner of real property pursuant to this chapter may be personally delivered or mailed by first class mail to the last known address of such owner. The city clerk or his or her designee shall execute a proper affidavit attesting to whom such notice was delivered or mailed, and the address to which such notice was directed. Such affidavit shall accompany any certification of charges to Sedgwick County for levy and collection. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.36.050 - Abatement by city. 
    In the event the responsible property owner fails or refuses to remove such material from a public street within the time specified in the notice, the city manager may direct that such material be removed and the nuisance be abated by city forces. Upon completion of such work, the city manager shall notify the responsible property owner of the cost thereof, including labor, materials and overhead. Such property owner shall reimburse the city for the entire cost thereof within thirty days next following the date of such notice. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.36.060 - Collection of unpaid costs of abatement. 
    Any portion of the cost of nuisance abatement hereunder which remains due and payable more than thirty days following the date of such notice to the responsible property owner shall become a lien upon the real property described in such notice, and shall be certified by the city clerk to Sedgwick County. Such unpaid costs shall be levied as an assessment against the real property described in such certification, and collected in the same manner as other taxes. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
Chapter 12.40 - MINOR STREET PRIVILEGES 
Sections: 

12.40.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
A.  "Minor street privilege" means any authorized or permitted private use in, on, under or over a public street, alley or way, which use is separate and distinct from the general public use thereof, and which is specifically authorized by the provisions of this chapter or by a permit issued in accordance with this chapter. The term shall not apply to temporary use of public land or space in connection with building construction governed by the building trade regulations of the city, or to activities of a public utility operating under a franchise granted by the city. 
B.  "Director" means the city's director of engineering. 
C.  "Permittee" means a person or entity in possession of a minor street privilege, regardless of whether such privilege is granted pursuant to Section 12.40.030 of this chapter or pursuant to a permit issued therefor; provided, that such person or entity is the owner or occupant of the private property abutting the encroachment, or is a homeowners association representing an area which includes the private property abutting the encroachment. 
D.  "Street" means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained, when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel; the term includes any street, avenue, boulevard, thoroughfare, trafficway, alley and other public way for vehicular traffic by whatever name, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
(Amended during Supp. No. 1, 11/03; Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.40.020 - Application of chapter. 
    The enjoyment and use of a minor street privilege by the permittee for private purposes, as hereinafter set forth in this chapter, shall be subject to permit requirements of and regulations adopted pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.40.030 - Minor street privileges not requiring a permit. 
A.  Any owner or occupant of residential property within the city may, without obtaining a permit therefor pursuant to this chapter, use that portion of the street abutting such property which is not otherwise occupied, used or improved for movement of vehicular or pedestrian traffic, for any of the following purposes: installation and maintenance of a driveway approach; planting and maintenance of a lawn; installation of irrigation or lawns sprinkling systems; and landscaping, including but not limited to planting and maintenance of shrubs and bushes not exceeding thirty-three inches in height as measured from the bottom of the curb of the adjacent street or, if no curb is installed, from the edge of the traveled roadway; street trees authorized by this code; and associated landscape features not which do not, in the judgment of the director, pose a hazard to vehicular or pedestrian traffic or create an impediment to street maintenance, snow removal operations, or other street improvement activities. 
B.  No annual fee or administrative charge shall be made for minor street privileges granted pursuant to this section. 
C.  Except as provided in this section or otherwise specifically authorized by city ordinance, no person shall make any other private use of the right-of-way of any street, alley or public way without first securing a minor street privilege permit pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.40.040 - Application for and issuance of a minor street privilege permit. 
A.  Application for a minor street privilege shall be submitted to the director in writing, accompanied by appropriate drawings, plans or photographs. The application shall be made by the owner, or occupant with the consent of the owner, of abutting land, or by the homeowners association representing the area which includes the private property abutting the public property requested for use; provided, that a minor street privilege permit issued to an occupant who is not also the owner of such property shall terminate at such time as the recipient ceases to occupy the property. 
B.  Upon receipt of an application under this section, the director shall approve the application, approve the application with such conditions as he or she finds reasonable to protect the public interest, or deny the application if he or she deems it inconsistent with the public interest. On approval of the application for a minor street privilege by the director and payment of the required fee, he or she shall issue the permit. 
C.  The director may grant renewals of permits previously granted under the provisions of this chapter upon the payment of annual permit fees to the clerk and continuation in force of surety bond and/or liability insurance for such renewals. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.40.050 - Unsafe conditions. 
    Notwithstanding any provision of this chapter, it is unlawful for any person to operate or maintain an underground sprinkler or irrigation system in any public right-of-way within the city in a manner that creates unsafe conditions for vehicles driving on adjacent streets or highways. If any unsafe condition occurs, the city shall, in addition to other remedies available to it at law or in equity, have authority to: 
A.  Order the owner or operator of the system to remove the system from the right-of-way or discontinue operating the system until it is repaired or the unsafe condition eliminated; or 
B.  Cause the system to be repaired, removed or disconnected at the owner's/operator's expense when deemed necessary by the city to protect traffic safety or the public water supply. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.40.060 - Allocation of risk of loss. 
A.  As a condition of the use or enjoyment of, or issuance of a permit for, any minor street privilege, the permittee shall save and hold the city harmless of any and all liability, claims or expenses of any kind caused by, or growing out of, the use, construction, maintenance, operation, relocation, discontinuance or abatement of any minor street privilege. 
B.  The city shall not be liable to a permittee, including an owner or operator of any underground (irrigation) sprinkler system, for any damage, except such damage as is caused by gross or wanton negligence, to that portion of such system located in a street when such results in whole or in part from construction, reconstruction, improvement, repair or maintenance, including snow removal and other street maintenance work performed by city forces; nor shall any person make a claim against the city, its employees or officers for damage to such improvements resulting in whole or in part from construction, reconstruction, improvement, repair or maintenance, including snow removal and other street maintenance, work performed within the street by the city or any person or firm under contract with the city, except such damage as is caused by gross or wanton negligence. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.40.070 - Bonds and liability insurance. 
    Whenever, in the opinion of the director, the construction, maintenance or abandonment of a minor street privilege permit, other than authorized by Section 12.40.030 of this chapter, is attended with the possibility of a substantial damage or loss to the city, to other property owners, or to members of the public, the applicant for such minor street privilege may be required to furnish and file with the city clerk, as a condition precedent to issuance of the permit, a surety bond or to provide proof of liability insurance naming the city as an additional insured and providing that the city will be given ten days prior notice of cancellation. The amount of such bond or the policy limits of such liability insurance shall be such as the director determines to be sufficient to protect against such damage or loss. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.40.080 - Restoration of streets. 
    The cost of all restoration, all adjustments in connection with utilities and all other adjustments made necessary by the construction, maintenance, operation, relocation, discontinuance or abandonment of any minor street privilege shall be paid by the permittee. All such restoration and other necessary work of adjustment shall be performed in accordance with the provisions of this code and any other ordinances, or in the absence of a regulatory ordinance, shall, at the option of the director, be performed by the permittee or by the city at the permittee's expense. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.40.090 - Termination for failure to pay permit fee. 
    In case any permittee shall fail to pay a required permit fee, with accrued penalties, for any minor street privilege within thirty days after the same shall be due and payable, the director shall declare the privilege terminated and shall immediately cause a notice of termination to be given the permittee. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.40.100 - Discontinuance of use and restoration of property. 
A.  Upon termination of a minor street privilege under the provisions of this chapter, the director shall notify the permittee to make all necessary arrangements for the discontinuance and abandonment of the privilege and make or cause restoration of the public property, all in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  If the permittee shall fail to make arrangements promptly, as required by this section, the director is authorized to perform the necessary work and charge the expense thereof to the permittee. In addition to the above cost, the permittee shall be charged with proportional permit fees for the period up to the date on which the work or restoration is completed. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.40.110 - Unlawful use of privilege. 
    No person shall make any use of a minor street privilege unless such use has been authorized in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, and the use of any minor street privilege for which a fee is imposed is prohibited unless the permit fee is paid as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.40.120 - Revocation of privilege-Proration of permit fees. 
    All minor street privileges provided for in this chapter are revocable for violation of the terms of the permit or of this chapter, or in the event the street right-of-way burdened by the privilege is, at the discretion of the director, needed for a duly authorized municipal use. Upon revocation of any minor street privilege during a period of time for which a permit fee has been paid, the city shall refund the annual fee paid on pro rata basis, as determined by the director. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.40.130 - Annual permit fees and charges-Exceptions. 
A.  Upon approval of a minor street privilege for which a permit is required under this chapter, the permittee desiring a minor street privilege shall, upon approval of the application therefor, pay the fee fixed therefor by resolution; provided, that the minimum annual permit fee for a minor street privilege permit shall be fifteen dollars. 
B.  An initial application for a minor street privilege for which issuance of a permit is required under this chapter shall be accompanied by an administrative charge of twenty-five dollars. 
C.  No annual permit fee shall be charged for a minor street privilege: 
1.  When the granting of such privilege is coupled with and is a part of the public requirement or consideration for the taking of land by the city in connection with the city's approval of a plat or lot split; 
2.  When the director determines the project to be one involving public safety, beautification or improvement of public property for public purposes; 
3.  For use of public right-of-way that has been fenced for private use prior to annexation by the city, for a period of ten years from the date of enactment of this section, or in the event such property is subsequently annexed, for a period of ten years after the date of annexation. A person eligible for waiver of payment of fees herein must make application for a minor street privilege within six months of the date of enactment of this section, or within six months following annexation, whichever is later. 
D.  The administrative charge shall accompany the application when a waiver of annual permit fee is requested. The application for a minor street privilege shall state the reasons for the waiver, and shall be accompanied by drawings, plans or photographs showing all encroachments and describing their nature and specifications. Upon the approval of the minor street privilege by the director, the appropriate drawings, plans or photographs shall be made a part of the permit, and the recipient of the minor street privilege, by acceptance thereof, shall be obligated to indemnify the city for any and all costs of removal of any unauthorized improvements not constructed in accordance with the document submitted and approved, or not included in the minor street privilege permit. 
E.  A person making application for such minor street privilege shall comply with all other provisions of this chapter in obtaining a minor street privilege permit, including the requirement to post a surety bond and/or provide proof of liability insurance naming the city as an additional insured. 
F.  Any person aggrieved by the action of the director with respect to an application for waiver of fees under this section may appeal ruling to the city council by requesting a hearing thereon within thirty days following notification of the decision of the director. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.40.140 - Penalty for failure to timely pay fees. 
    All permits not paid for within thirty days after the due date shall be subject to a penalty of ten percent of the amount of the permit fee, and ten percent of the amount of the permit fee shall be added for each additional thirty-day period, or part thereof, from and after the due date. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.40.150 - Civil action to recover fees, charges and restoration costs. 
    In addition to the penalty prescribed in Section 12.40.140 of this chapter, the city may recover in a civil action in any court of competent jurisdiction, the amount of the permit fees imposed and/or the action cost of restoration. No property of such debtor shall be exempt from forced sale under any process of law for such indebtedness, except such exemptions as are allowed by the constitution and laws of this state. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.40.160 - Limitation on new encroachments. 
    Notwithstanding any provision of this chapter, all encroachments on public streets, alleys or ways shall continue to be subject to all applicable laws, provisions of this code and other ordinances and regulations of the city. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.40.170 - Application of inspection, construction and other permit fees. 
    All permit fees established for the enjoyment of minor street privileges shall be separate from and in addition to inspection, construction and other permit fees established by city ordinance. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
12.40.180 - Rules and regulations. 
    The city manager or his or her designee may prepare and enforce reasonable rules and regulations to implement the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1595 § 1 (part), 1997) 
Title 13 - WATER AND SEWERS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 13.04 - WATER RATES 
Sections: 

13.04.010 - Authority. 
    The ordinance codified in this chapter is adopted in accordance with K.S.A. 66-104 and K.S.A. 66-133. 
(Ord. 1280 § 1, 1985: Ord. 1093 § 1, 1980) 
13.04.020 - Rates and charges applicable to retail water customers. 
A.  The following rates and charges shall apply to monthly water service billed to retail customers on or after February 1, 2012, by El Paso Water Company, Inc. (the "company"). The monthly charge for each customer shall be equal to the sum of the base charge and the charge or charges for all water supplied to such customer in excess of two thousand gallons in one month. 
Quantity Supplied Rate/Charge 2,000 gal. or less $13.32 (base charge) More than 2,000 gal. but not more than 6,000 gal. $2.66 per 1,000 gal. More than 6,000 gal. but not more than 10,000 gal. $3.04 per 1,000 gal. More than 10,000 gal. but not more than 20,000 gal. $3.49 per 1,000 gal. More than 20,000 gal. but not more than 40,000 gal. $4.05 per 1,000 gal. More than 40,000 gal. $4.71 per 1,000 gal.  
B.  In the event of an increase in the cost of water purchased by the company, the city manager may increase the rates established by subsection A hereof by an amount not to exceed such amount or percentage increase in cost. 
(Ord. 1887 § 1, 2007) 
(Ord. No. 2102, § 1, 12-13-11) 
13.04.050 - Extensions. 
A.  In an effort to resolve the problems relating to the extension of water service to new areas of the city, the council institutes the following procedure: commencing with calendar year 1981, all extensions of water mains to new developments, including residential, business or industrial, in the city, shall be financed and installed by the city under the city's capital improvements program. The plans and specifications for such extensions shall be as directed and approved by the city engineer and shall be constructed and installed under his supervision and final inspection. These extensions will be assessed to the benefit district in accordance with state law. This will give the citizens and users of water in the city the benefit of competitive bidding in the letting of the contracts, as well as permitting a lower interest rate for the financing of the improvements. 
B.  Any such extensions built by the city shall be and remain the sole property of the city. The El Paso Water Co., Inc., shall supply water to customers on said city-owned systems and shall be allowed to charge each customer for water provided, at the rates lawfully established by this chapter. The company shall, in consideration of this privilege, maintain the city-owned system at its own expense. All expenses incurred, however, in connection with the maintenance of any such city-owned system, may be claimed by the company in future rate proceedings. 
(Ord. 1093 § 5, 1980) 
13.04.060 - Rate of return report. 
    The company shall file with the city manager by April 1, 1983, and each year thereafter, a report, to be prepared in accordance with standard utility rate making procedures and to be certified by a public accountant, showing the rate of return on its useful plant in service for the twelve-month period ending the preceding December 31st. The city may, upon application of the company or on its own initiative, provide rate relief, as may be appropriate. 
(Ord. 1169 § 1, 1982: Ord. 1093 § 6, 1980) 
13.04.070 - Penalty for violation. 
A.  If the company violates any of the provisions of this chapter, does any act herein prohibited, or fails or refuses to perform any duty imposed herein, it shall, for each such violation, failure or refusal, forfeit and pay to the city treasurer an amount not less than one hundred dollars, and not more than one thousand dollars for such offense. 
B.  Any act, omission or failure of any officer, agent or other person acting for or employed by the company while acting within the scope of their employment, shall be deemed to be the act, omission or failure of the company, and every day during which the company or officer, agent or employee thereof fails to comply with any order or direction of the council, as embodied by this chapter, shall constitute a separate and distinct violation of this section. 
C.  If the council finds probable cause to believe that the provisions of this chapter have been violated in any manner specified in this section, it shall order the company, by certified letter, to appear at a hearing to show cause, if any, why the penalties specified herein should not be imposed. The council shall, at the conclusion of said hearing, grant whatever relief it deems appropriate or it may impose a penalty as set forth herein. 
(Ord. 1093 § 8, 1980) 
Chapter 13.06 - EMERGENCY WATER REGULATIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Sections 1 and 2 of Ord. No. 2161, adopted June 11, 2013, repealed the former Ch. 13.06, §§ 13.06.010-13.06.090, and enacted a new Ch. 13.06 as set out herein. The former Ch. 13.06 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 1635, § 1(part), adopted in 1998. 

13.06.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide for declaration of a Stage 1 Voluntary Conservation, Stage 2 Mandatory Restrictions, or Stage 3 Water Emergency and the implementation of voluntary and mandatory water conservation measures throughout the city in the event of such a declaration. 
(Ord. No. 2161, § 1, 6-11-13; Ord. No. 2345, § 1, 2-27-18) 
13.06.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter: 
A.  "Water" means water supplied by the company to its customers. 
B.  "Company" means the El Paso Water Company, Inc., of Derby, Kansas, or any successor in interest. 
C.  "Customer" means the company's customer of record at or with respect to any property to which water is supplied by the company, and for which either a regular charge is made or a cash charge is made at the site of delivery. 
D.  "Waste of water" includes, but is not limited to: (1) permitting water to escape down a gutter, ditch, or other surface drain; or (2) failure to repair or stop a controllable leak of water. 
E.  "Water conservation plan" means the municipal water conservation plan prepared by the company and filed with the city clerk, as it may be from time to time supplemented or amended. 
(Ord. No. 2161, § 1, 6-11-13) 
13.06.030 - Stage 1: Voluntary Conservation. 
    Whenever the city manager finds that a trigger identified in the water conservation plan has occurred, the city council by resolution or the city manager may declare that a Stage 1 Voluntary Conservation is required pursuant to the water conservation plan. The stage shall continue until terminated by the city council or city manager. Any declaration, order, or resolution declaring or terminating the Stage 1: Voluntary Conservation shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall be filed promptly with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2161, § 1, 6-11-13; Ord. No. 2345, § 2, 2-27-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2345, § 2, adopted Feb. 27, 2018, changed the title of § 13.06.030 from "Water watch" to read as herein set out. 
13.06.040 - Stage 2: Mandatory Restrictions. 
    Whenever the city manager finds that a trigger identified in the water conservation plan has occurred, the city council by resolution or the city manager may declare that a Stage 2 Mandatory Restrictions is required pursuant to the water conservation plan. The stage shall continue until terminated by the city council or city manager. Any declaration, order, or resolution declaring or terminating the Stage 2 Mandatory Restrictions shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall be filed promptly with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2161, § 1, 6-11-13; Ord. No. 2345, § 3, 2-27-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2345, § 3, adopted Feb. 27, 2018, changed the title of § 13.06.040 from "Water warning" to read as herein set out. 
13.06.050 - Stage 3: Water Emergency. 
    Whenever the city manager finds that a trigger identified in the water conservation plan has occurred, the city council by resolution or the city manager may declare that a Stage 3 Water Emergency is required pursuant to the water conservation plan. The stage shall continue until terminated by the city council or city manager. Any declaration, order, or resolution declaring or terminating a Stage 3 Water Emergency shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall be filed promptly with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2161, § 1, 6-11-13; Ord. No. 2345, § 4, 2-27-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2345, § 4, adopted Feb. 27, 2018, changed the title of § 13.06.050 from "Water emergency" to read as herein set out. 
13.06.060 - Emergency water rates; excessive use charges. 
    Upon declaration of a Stage 2 Mandatory Restrictions or Stage 3 Water Emergency, the city council may adopt emergency water rates and may impose excessive use charges or fees for the purpose of ensuring compliance with and conserving water supplies pursuant to the water conservation plan. 
(Ord. No. 2161, § 1, 6-11-13; Ord. No. 2345, § 5, 2-27-18) 
13.06.070 - Emergency regulations. 
    During a Stage 3 Water Emergency declared pursuant to this chapter, the city manager is empowered to promulgate, implement and enforce such regulations deemed necessary to carry out the provisions of this chapter. Such regulations shall be subject to approval of the city council at its next regular or special meeting. 
(Ord. No. 2161, § 1, 6-11-13; Ord. No. 2345, § 6, 2-27-18) 
13.06.080 - Correction, cure or abatement of violations; disconnection for violation. 
A.  Whenever a violation of any water conservation plan regulations implemented pursuant to the declaration of a Stage 2 Mandatory Restrictions or Stage 3 Water Emergency occurs, written notice of the violation shall be given to the customer or any other person known or believed to be responsible for the property where the violation occurs, or affixed to the property where the violation occurs. Such notice shall include a description of the violation and state the following: 
1.  The property is in violation of this chapter; 
2.  The customer or any other person known or believed to be responsible for the property where the violation occurs is ordered to correct, cure or abate such violation within forty-eight hours after receipt of notice; 
3.  If the violation is not abated within forty-eight hours, the city or its authorized agent may correct, cure or abate the violation and charge the cost thereof, including reasonable administrative fees established in the water conservation plan for violations of plan restrictions, to the customer; 
4.  Such costs and fees, if not timely paid, will be assessed as a special assessment against the property upon which the violation is located; 
5.  No further notice is required to be given prior to correction, cure, or abatement of violations by the city: and correction, cure, or abatement may include disconnection of services; 
B.  In the event the customer or any other person responsible for the property where the violation occurs fails or refuses to correct, cure, or abate a violation of this chapter upon notice thereof pursuant to subsection A., the city may cause the violation to be corrected, cured or abated and the cost thereof, including reasonable administrative fees established in the water conservation plan for violations of plan restrictions, to be charged against the customer and, if such charges and fees are not timely paid, may certify the same to the city clerk to be levied as a special assessment against the property upon which the violation was located. Correction, cure or abatement by the city may include disconnection of services. 
C.  A fee of fifty dollars shall be paid for the reconnection of any water service terminated pursuant to this Section 13.06.080. In the event of a second or subsequent disconnection by or with respect to the same property, the reconnection fee shall be two hundred dollars for the second reconnection and five hundred dollars for all subsequent reconnections. 
(Ord. No. 2161, § 1, 6-11-13; Ord. No. 2345, § 7, 2-27-18) 
13.06.090 - Immediate disconnection of water service. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prohibit the city from disconnecting or terminating the supply of water to any or all customers upon a determination that immediate termination of water service is necessary to protect the health and safety of the public. 
(Ord. No. 2161, § 1, 6-11-13) 
Chapter 13.08 - SEWERS AND DRAINS 
Sections: 
I. - General Provisions 

13.08.010 - Definitions. 
    Unless the contents specifically indicate otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this chapter shall be as follows: 
A.  "Building drain" means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. 
B.  "Building sewer" means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
C.  "City" means the city of Derby, Kansas, acting through its duly elected and appointed officials. 
D.  "Garbage" means solid wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
E.  "Industrial wastes" means the liquid wastes from industrial processes as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
F.  "Inspector" means the inspector of the sewer system of the city or his authorized deputy, agent or representative. 
G.  "Natural outlet" means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface or ground water. 
H.  "Person" means any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation or group. 
I.  "Properly shredded garbage" means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
J.  "Public sewer" means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and is controlled by public authority. 
K.  "Sanitary sewer" means a sewer which carries sewage and to which storm, surface, and ground waters are not intentionally admitted. 
L.  "Sewage" means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments. 
M.  "Sewer" means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
N.  "Shall" is mandatory, "may" is permissive. 
O.  "Storm sewer" means a sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and polluted industrial wastes. 
P.  "Suspended solids" means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in, water, sewage or other liquids and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
(Ord. 746 § 1, 1968) 
II. - Unlawful Acts 

13.08.020 - Deposit of unsanitary materials. 
    It is unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in an unsanitary manner upon public or private property within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(Ord. 746 § 2(a), 1968) 
13.08.030 - Discharges into watercourses. 
    It is unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any sanitary sewage, industrial wastes or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with the city and county health department. 
(Ord. 746 § 2(b), 1968) 
13.08.040 - Construction or maintenance of private sewers. 
    It is unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(Ord. 746 § 2(c), 1968) 
13.08.050 - Unlawful discharge to sanitary sewer. 
A.  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, ground-water, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, cooling water or unpolluted industrial process water to any sanitary sewer. 
B.  No person shall be convicted of a violation of this section unless such person has been furnished a written notice from the city's building official, describing such improper connection and establishing a time within which correction thereof is to be made, and such person has failed or refused to make such correction within the time specified. 
C.  Unlawful discharge to a sanitary sewer is a class "C" violation. 
(Ord. 1698 § 1, 2000) 
(Ord. No. 2119, § 1, 7-24-12) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 2119, adopted July 24, 2012, changed the title of § 13.08.050 from "Unlawful discharges" to "Unlawful discharge to sanitary sewer." 
III. - Permits 

13.08.060 - Fees. 
    The following sewer permit fees are established: 
A.  Connection Permit. 
1.  Commercial, $100.00; 
2.  Residential. 
a.  First two connections, $100.00 ea., 
b.  Next two connections, $50.00 ea., 
c.  Fifth and each additional unit, $25.00 ea.; 
B.  Repair or extension permit, $10.00; 
C.  Seal-off permit, $10.00; 
D.  Tap fee, $80.00. 
(Ord. 1263 § 1, 1984) 
13.08.063 - Right of easement not included. 
    A permit to connect to a city sewer does not include the right to construct a sewer or drain across the property belonging to some other person. Such right must be obtained from the owner of such property and should be in the form of a legal easement and shall be filed in the office of the register of deeds. 
(Ord. 1263 § 2, 1984) 
IV. - Connections 

13.08.066 - Notice and supervision of taps made by permittee. 
    The permittee shall make all taps in clay tile sewer mains. In all cases where a tap is to be made in clay tile mains, in PVC, or in ABS mains, the inspection department shall be notified and the work performed by the permittee under the supervision of the city. 
(Ord. 1263 § 3, 1984) 
13.08.069 - Taps in PVC or ABS mains made by contractor. 
    In all cases where a licensed contractor makes a tap in PVC or ABS mains, the city inspector shall be notified and present at the time the tap is made. The tap shall be made with a four and three-eighths inch hole saw with integral pilot bit. 
(Ord. 1263 § 5, 1984) 
13.08.072 - Saddles-Who supplies. 
    A four-inch saddle, manufactured of appropriate material, shall be furnished by the city. Saddles of larger sizes shall be furnished by the contractor. 
(Ord. 1263 § 4, 1984) 
13.08.075 - Saddle specifications when supplied by contractor. 
    The saddle supplied by the contractor shall be manufactured of the same material as the sewer main (PVC or ABS) and shall be properly solvent weld cemented and banded into place. 
(Ord. 1263 § 6, 1984) 
13.08.080 - Owner responsibility. 
A.  The owner of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the city is required, at his expense, to install suitable toilet facilities therein and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  All costs and expense incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(Ord. 746 §§ 2(d), 4(a), 1968) 
13.08.090 - Interceptor installation. 
    Grease, oil and sand interceptors or traps shall be provided in all filling stations, public garages and other commercial buildings where vehicles are washed or serviced and in all other commercial or industrial buildings when, in the opinion of the inspector, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand and other harmful ingredients. All interceptors or traps shall be of a type and capacity approved by the inspector and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. Where installed all grease, oil and sand interceptors or traps shall be maintained by the owner, at his expense, in continuously efficient operation at all times. 
(Ord. 746 § 5(b), 1968) 
13.08.100 - Separate sewers-Old sewers. 
A.  A separate and independent sewer shall be provided for each residential building. 
B.  Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found on examination and test by the inspector to meet all requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. 746 § 4(b), (c), 1968) 
13.08.110 - Pipes-Generally. 
    The building sewer shall be cast iron soil pipe or vitrified clay sewer pipe. Joints shall be tight and waterproof. Any part of the building sewer that is located within ten feet of a water service pipe shall be constructed of cast iron soil pipe with leaded joints. Cast iron pipe with leaded joints may be required by the inspector where the building sewer is exposed to damage by tree roots. If installed in filled or unstable ground, the building sewer shall be of cast iron soil pipe, except that vitrified clay tile may be accepted if laid on a suitable concrete bed or cradle as approved by the inspector. Cast iron soil pipe will be used when laid closer than four feet to any building or through and under any concrete. 
(Ord. 746 § 4(d), 1968) 
13.08.120 - Size and slope-Fixture units. 
    The size and slope of the building sewer shall be subject to the approval of the inspector, but in no event shall the diameter be less than four inches. The table of fixture units for the size of building sewer shall be as follows: 
    Four inch at one-eighth inch per foot slope - 130 fixture units 
    Four inch at one-quarter inch per foot slope - 166 fixture units 
    Four inch at one-half inch per foot slope - 200 fixture units 
    Six inch at one-eighth inch per foot slope - 650 fixture units 
    Six inch at one-quarter inch per foot slope - 790 fixture units 
    Six inch at one-half inch per foot slope - 950 fixture units 
    Eight inch at one-eighth inch per foot slope - 1550 fixture units 
    Eight inch at one-quarter inch per foot slope - 1870 fixture units 
    Eight inch at one-half inch per foot slope - 2250 fixture units 
    The slope of the pipe shall be not less than one-eighth inch per foot, and should be one-quarter inch per foot where possible. 
(Ord. 746 § 4(c), 1968) 
13.08.130 - Laying requirements. 
    No building sewer shall be laid parallel to or within three feet of any bearing wall which might thereby be weakened. The depth shall be sufficient to afford protection from frost. The building sewer shall be laid at uniform grade and in straight alignment insofar as possible. Changes in direction shall be made only with properly curved pipe and fittings. 
(Ord. 746 § 4(f), 1968) 
13.08.140 - Lifting by artificial means. 
    In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such drain shall be lifted by approved artificial means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(Ord. 746 § 4(g), 1968) 
13.08.150 - Excavation-Type. 
    All excavations required for the installation of a building sewer shall be open trench work unless otherwise approved by the inspector. No backfill shall be placed until the work has been inspected. 
(Ord. 746 § 4(h), 1968) 
13.08.160 - Pipes-Type. 
    Sewer pipes shall be of the following types in accordance with specifications given and shall be free from defects and cracks; bowed or curved lengths shall be termed defective and not used: 
A.  Vitrified glazed clay pipes conforming to the requirements of ASTM Designation, C 200-64T and the latest revision thereof with factory installed resilient couplings conforming to ASTM Designation C 425-64 and the latest revisions thereof. Lubricant sealer is to be used as recommended by the manufacturer. No part of any building sewer or drain, constructed of vitrified clay pipe, shall be less than one foot below the surface of the ground. 
B.  Service weight or extra heavy cast-iron bell and spigot soil pipe and fittings coated inside and out meeting Commercial Standard CS-188. Joints shall be firmly packed with packed oakum or hemp and secured with molten lead with at least twelve ounces of fine soft caulking lead being used for each inch of the pipe diameter for each joint, or the joints where properly applied to suitable cast-iron bell and spigot pipe and fittings shall be made with an approved neoprene gasket which is compressed as the spigot is inserted into the bell of the pipe. 
(Ord. 746 § 4(i), 1968) 
13.08.170 - Method and location. 
    The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall be made at the wye branch if such wye branch is available at a suitable location. If no properly located wye branch is available, the owner shall, at his own expense, install a wye branch or an approved saddle at the location specified by the inspector. Where permitted by the inspector, a neat hole may be cut into the public sewer to receive the building sewer, with entry in the downstream direction at an angle of about forty-five degree ell may be used to make such connection, with the spigot end cut so as not to extend past the inner surface of the public sewer. The invert of the building sewer at the point of connection shall be at the same or a higher elevation than the invert of the public sewer. A smooth neat joint shall be made, and the connection made secure and water-tight and encased in concrete. 
(Ord. 746 § 4(j), 1968) 
13.08.180 - Notice to inspect. 
    The permit holder shall be responsible for notifying the inspector when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the inspector or his representative. 
(Ord. 746 § 4(k), 1968) 
13.08.190 - Excavation-Safety precautions-Restoration. 
    All excavation for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(Ord. 746 § 4(l), 1968) 
IV-A. - Clean-Out Operations 

13.08.193 - When permit not required-Tool retrieved. 
    A permit shall not be required on sewer clean-out operations in which the private sewer or drain can be cleaned out by cables, rods or flushing. In the event any cleaning tool is lost or cannot be retrieved from a sewer line, the person conducting the clean-out operation shall notify the city superintendent of public works immediately. Any cost associated with the recovery of any such tools shall be borne by the person or firm conducting the clean-out operation. 
(Ord. 1263 § 7, 1984) 
13.08.195 - Obstructions-Removal. 
    It shall be the duty of the person conducting the sewer clean-out operation to remove obstructions found in the course of cleaning a building sewer or drain, rather than dislodging the obstruction into the city's sewer where a stoppage may be caused. If an obstruction is dislodged which may cause a stoppage, the person conducting the sewer cleaning operation shall immediately notify the superintendent of public works. 
(Ord. 1263 § 8, 1984) 
13.08.197 - Installation of compatible materials. 
    When a building sewer line must be opened for cleaning purposes, a clean-out and fittings manufactured of compatible material must be installed at the point where the opening was made. 
(Ord. 1263 § 9, 1984) 
V. - Administration 

13.08.200 - Powers of inspectors. 
    The inspector and other duly authorized employees of the city shall be permitted to enter upon all properties for the purpose of inspecting, observing, measuring, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of Section 1.08.010 of this code. 
(Ord. 746 § 6, 1968) 
13.08.210 - Violation-Penalty. 
A.  Any person found to be violating any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be fined in an amount not exceeding one hundred dollars for each violation. Each day in which any such violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense. 
B.  Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall become liable to the city for such expense, loss or damage occasioned the city by reason of such violation. 
(Ord. 746 § 7, 1968) 
Chapter 13.12 - SEWERS-WASTES AND DISCHARGES 
Sections: 
I. - General Provisions 

13.12.010 - Definitions. 
    Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this chapter shall be as follows: 
A.  "BOD" (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at twenty degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
B.  "Building drain" means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. 
C.  "Building sewer" means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
D.  "Combined sewer" means a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. 
E.  "Garbage" means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
F.  "Industrial wastes" mean the liquid wastes from industrial manufacturing processes, trade or business as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
G.  "Natural outlet" means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of surface or groundwater. 
H.  "Person" means any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation or group. 
I.  "pH" means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution. 
J.  "Properly shredded garbage" means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
K.  "Public sewer" means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and is controlled by public authority. 
L.  "Sanitary sewer" means a sewer which carries sewage and to which stormwater, surface water and groundwater is not intentionally admitted. 
M.  "Sewage" means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments, together with such groundwater, surface water and stormwater as may be present. 
N.  "Sewage treatment plant" means any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage. 
O.  "Sewage works" means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage. 
P.  "Sewer" means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
Q.  "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissive. 
R.  "Slug" means any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen minutes more than five times the average twenty-four-hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
S.  "Storm drain" (sometimes termed "storm sewer") means a sewer which carries stormwater and surface water and drainage, but excludes sewage and industrial wastes, other than unpolluted cooling water. 
T.  "Superintendent" means the city clerk, superintendent of public works, zoning administrator of the city, or authorized deputy, agent, or representative. 
U.  "Suspended solids" means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in water, sewage or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
V.  "Watercourse" means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Ord. 1057 § 1, 1979) 
II. - Unlawful Acts 

13.12.020 - Unlawful deposit of wastes. 
    It is unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(Ord. 1057 § 2(A), 1979) 
13.12.030 - Unlawful discharge to natural outlet. 
    It is unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1057 § 2(B), 1979) 
13.12.040 - Construction or maintenance of sewage disposal facilities. 
    Except as hereinafter provided, it is unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(Ord. 1057 § 2(C), 1979) 
13.12.050 - Destruction or damage. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is part of the sewage works. Any person violating this provision shall be subject to immediate arrest under charge of disorderly conduct. 
(Ord. 1057 § 6, 1979) 
III. - Permits 

13.12.060 - Permit-Required. 
    No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the superintendent. 
(Ord. 1057 § 4(A), 1979) 
13.12.070 - Permit-Application. 
    The owners or their agents shall make application for sewer permits in accordance with Section 13.08.075. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information pertinent in the judgment of the superintendent. 
(Ord. 1057 § 4(B), 1979) 
13.12.080 - Applicant-Notification for inspection and connection. 
    The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the superintendent when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the superintendent or his representative. 
(Ord. 1057 § 4(J), 1979) 
IV. - Installation and Connection 

13.12.090 - Installation and connection-Required. 
    The owner of all houses, buildings or properties used for human employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary or combined sewer of the city, is required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, within ninety days after date of official notice to do so; provided, that the public sewer is within one hundred feet of the property line. 
(Ord. 1057 § 2(D), 1979) 
13.12.100 - Connection to private sewage disposal system. 
    Where a public sanitary or combined sewer is not available under the provisions of Section 13.12.090, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of Sections 13.12.100 through 13.12.170. 
(Ord. 1057 § 3(A), 1979) 
13.12.110 - Construction of private system-Permit required. 
    Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system, the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the superintendent. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the city, which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications, and other information as are deemed necessary by the superintendent. A permit and inspection fee as set by the city council shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. 
(Ord. 1057 § 3(B), 1979) 
13.12.120 - Private system-Inspection. 
    A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the superintendent. He shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the superintendent when the work is ready for final inspection, and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within twenty-four hours of the receipt of notice by the superintendent. 
(Ord. 1057 § 3(C), 1979) 
13.12.130 - Private system-Specifications. 
    The type, capacities, location and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the Wichita-Sedgwick County Health Department. No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities where the area of the lot is less than twenty thousand square feet. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. 
(Ord. 1057 § 3(D), 1979) 
13.12.140 - Private system-Operation and maintenance. 
    The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. 
(Ord. 1057 § 3(F), 1979) 
13.12.150 - Availability of public sewer-Connection required. 
    At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system, as provided in Section 13.12.130, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this chapter, and any septic tanks, cesspools and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material. 
(Ord. 1057 § 3(E), 1979) 
13.12.160 - Availability of public sewer-Cleaning and filling of private system. 
    When a public sewer becomes available, the building sewer shall be connected to the sewer within sixty days, and the private sewage disposal system shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with clean bankrun gravel or dirt. 
(Ord. 1057 § 3(H), 1979) 
13.12.170 - Additional requirements. 
    No statement contained in Sections 13.12.090 through 13.12.170 shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the health officer. 
(Ord. 1057 § 3(G), 1979) 
13.12.180 - Installation and connection-Costs and expenses. 
    All costs and expense incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(Ord. 1057 § 4(C), 1979) 
13.12.190 - Connection-Specifications. 
    The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. All such connections shall be gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the superintendent before installation. 
(Ord. 1057 § 4(I), 1979) 
13.12.200 - Separate and independent building sewer. 
    A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except where one building stands at the rear of another building under the same ownership on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, courtyard or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. 
(Ord. 1057 § 4(D), 1979) 
13.12.210 - Old building sewers. 
    Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the superintendent, to meet all requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1057 § 4(E), 1979) 
13.12.220 - Materials, methods and requirements. 
    The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating and placing of the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. 
(Ord. 1057 § 4(F), 1979) 
13.12.230 - Building sewer elevation. 
    Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(Ord. 1057 § 4(G), 1979) 
13.12.240 - Unlawful connections. 
    No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, interior and exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. 1057 § 4(H), 1979) 
13.12.250 - Excavations. 
    All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(Ord. 1057 § 4(K), 1979) 
V. - Discharge of Waters or Wastes 

13.12.260 - Prohibited discharges to sanitary sewer. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, including interior and exterior foundation drains, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. 1057 § 5(A), 1979) 
13.12.270 - Discharge of unpolluted drainage on process waters. 
    Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as combined sewers or storm sewers or to a natural outlet approved by the superintendent. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged on approval of the superintendent, to a storm sewer, combined sewer, or natural outlet. 
(Ord. 1057 § 5(B), 1979) 
13.12.280 - Prohibited discharges to public sewer. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public sewers: 
A.  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas; 
B.  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant, including but not limited to cyanides in excess of two mg/l as CN in the wastes as discharged to the public sewer; 
C.  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5, or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and personnel of the sewage works; 
D.  Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole or ground by garbage grinders. 
(Ord. 1057 § 5(C), 1979) 
13.12.290 - Prohibited discharge of harmful wastes. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following described substances, materials, waters, or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of the superintendent that such wastes can harm either the sewers, sewage treatment process, or equipment; have an adverse effect on the receiving stream; or can otherwise endanger life, limb or public property; or constitute a nuisance. In forming his opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes, the superintendent will give consideration to such factors as the quantities of subject wastes in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers, nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of the sewage treatment plant, degree of treatability of wastes in the sewage treatment plant, and other pertinent factors. The substances prohibited are: 
A.  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit (sixty-five degrees Centigrade); 
B.  Any water or wastes containing fats, wax, grease or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred mg/1 or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between thirty-two and one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit (zero and sixty-five degrees Centigrade); 
C.  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to the review and approval of the superintendent; 
D.  Any waters or wastes containing strong acid iron pickling wastes, or concentrated plating solutions whether neutralized or not; 
E.  Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc and similar objectionable or toxic substances; or wastes exerting an excessive chlorine requirement, to such degree that any such material received in the composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the limits established by the superintendent for such materials; 
F.  Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste-producing or odor-producing substances, in such concentrations exceeding limits which may be established by the superintendent as necessary, after treatment of the composite sewage, to meet the requirements of state, federal or other public agencies of jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters; 
G.  Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the superintendent in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations; 
H.  Any waters or wastes having a pH in excess of 9.5; 
I.  Materials which exert or cause: 
1.  Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids such as but not limited to Fullers earth, lime slurries, and lime residues; or of dissolved solids such as but not limited to sodium chloride or sodium sulfate, 
2.  Excessive discoloration such as but not limited to dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions, 
3.  Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand, or chlorine requirements in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the sewage treatment works, 
4.  Unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes constituting slugs as defined in this chapter; 
J.  Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment processes employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters; 
K.  Any waters or wastes having: A five-day BOD greater than three hundred parts per million by weight, or containing more than three hundred fifty parts per million by weight of suspended solids, or having an average daily flow greater than two percent of the average sewage flow of the city, shall be subject to the review of the superintendent. Where necessary in the opinion of the superintendent, the owner shall provide, at his expense, such preliminary treatment as may be necessary to reduce the biochemical oxygen demand to three hundred parts per million by weight, or reduce the suspended solids to three hundred fifty parts per million by weight, or control the quantities and rates of discharge of such waters or wastes. Plans, specifications and any other pertinent information relating to proposed preliminary treatment facilities shall be submitted for the approval of the superintendent and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced until the approvals are obtained in writing. 
(Ord. 1057 § 5(D), 1979) 
13.12.300 - Hazardous discharges-Decision by superintendent. 
A.  If any waters or wastes are discharged, or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in Section 13.12.290, and which in the judgment of the superintendent, may have a deleterious effect upon the sewage works, processes, equipment or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life to constitute a public nuisance, the superintendent may: 
1.  Reject the wastes; 
2.  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; 
3.  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or 
4.  Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges under the provisions of Section 13.12.350. 
B.  If the superintendent permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the superintendent, and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, ordinances and laws. 
(Ord. 1057 § 5(E), 1979) 
13.12.310 - Grease, oil and sand interceptors. 
    Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the superintendent, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients; except, that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the superintendent, and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(Ord. 1057 § 5(F), 1979) 
13.12.320 - Preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities. 
    Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. 
(Ord. 1057 § 5(G), 1979) 
13.12.330 - Control manhole. 
    When required by the superintendent, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole, together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the superintendent. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(Ord. 1057 § 5(H), 1979) 
13.12.340 - Measurements, tests and analyses. 
    All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes, to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," published by the American Public Health Association, and shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples taken at the control manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb and property. The particular analyses involved will determine whether a twenty-four-hour composite of all outfalls of a premise is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analyses are obtained from twenty-four-hour composites of all outfalls whereas pH's are determined from periodic grab samples. 
(Ord. 1057 § 5(I), 1979) 
13.12.350 - Exceptions. 
    No statement contained in this article shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern, whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the city for treatment, subject to payment therefor, by the industrial concern. 
(Ord. 1057 § 5(J), 1979) 
VI. - Administration 

13.12.360 - Authority-Generally. 
    The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The superintendent or his representatives shall have no authority to inquire into any processes including metallurgical, chemical, oil, refining, ceramic, paper, or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterways or facilities for waste treatment. 
(Ord. 1057 § 7(A), 1979) 
13.12.370 - Safety rules. 
    While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in Section 13.12.360, the superintendent or duly authorized employees of the city shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company; and the company shall be held harmless for injury or death to the city employees; and the city shall indemnify the company against loss or damage to its property by city employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company, and growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the company to maintain safe conditions as required in Section 13.12.330. 
(Ord. 1057 § 7(B), 1979) 
13.12.380 - Right of entry. 
    The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the city holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair and maintenance of any portion of the sewage works lying within the easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on the easement, shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(Ord. 1057 § 7(C), 1979) 
VII. - Violation and Penalty 

13.12.390 - Designated. 
A.  Any person found to be violating any provisions of this chapter, except Section 13.12.050, shall be served by the city with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. 
The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. 
B.
